paras.en: When I wake up, the other side of the bed is cold. My fingers stretch out, seeking Prim’s warmth but finding only the rough canvas cover of the mattress. She must have had bad dreams and climbed in with our mother. Of course, she did. This is the day of the reaping.
paras.cn: 我醒来时，床的另一边是冷的。我的手指伸出去，寻找波丽姆的温暖，但只找到床垫粗糙的帆布罩。她一定是做了噩梦，爬到我们母亲那边去了。她当然会这么做。今天是“收获日”的日子。

vocab.ex: He likes to stretch out on the sofa after a long day.
vocab.tr: 劳累一天后，他喜欢在沙发上舒展身体。

vocab.ex: The company is actively seeking a new manager.
vocab.tr: 该公司正在积极寻找一位新经理。

vocab.ex: The old book had a rough, leather-bound cover.
vocab.tr: 那本旧书有一个粗糙的皮质封面。

vocab.mean: 收获；（文中的）收获日（一种抽签仪式）
vocab.ex: The reaping of the corn happens in late autumn.
vocab.tr: 玉米的收割发生在晚秋。

gram.name: 用于设定基调的并置手法
gram.pattern: Contrast between expectation and reality.
gram.function: 通过“寻找温暖”（seeking Prim’s warmth）与“只找到冰冷粗糙的帆布”（finding only the rough canvas cover）的并置对比，作者在开篇就建立了一种失落、严酷和不安的基调，为故事的背景定下了情感色彩。

example.en: He expected a joyful welcome but was met with a cold silence.
example.tr: 他期待着一个欢乐的欢迎，但迎接他的却是冰冷的沉默。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比来营造氛围的有效技巧。

paras.en: I prop myself up on one elbow. There’s enough light in the bedroom to see them. My little sister, Prim, curled up on her side, cocooned in my mother’s body, their cheeks pressed together. In sleep, my mother looks younger, still worn but not so beaten-down. Prim’s face is as fresh as a raindrop, as lovely as the primrose for which she was named. My mother was very beautiful once, too. Or so they tell me.
paras.cn: 我用一只手肘撑起自己。卧室里有足够的光线能看到她们。我的小妹妹波丽姆，侧身蜷缩着，像蚕茧一样被包裹在我母亲的怀里，她们的脸颊紧贴在一起。在睡梦中，我的母亲看起来更年轻，虽然依旧疲惫，但没那么憔悴不堪。波丽姆的脸像雨滴一样清新，像她名字由来的报春花一样可爱。我的母亲曾经也非常美丽。至少他们是这么告诉我的。

vocab.ex: He had to prop up the broken table leg with a stack of books.
vocab.tr: 他不得不用一摞书把坏掉的桌腿撑起来。

vocab.mean: 像在茧里一样被包裹的
vocab.ex: She felt warm and safe, cocooned in the thick blanket.
vocab.tr: 她感觉温暖又安全，被厚厚的毯子包裹着。

vocab.ex: His face looked old and worn after years of hard labor.
vocab.tr: 经过多年的辛勤劳动，他的脸看起来苍老而疲惫。

vocab.ex: The constant stress left him feeling beaten-down and hopeless.
vocab.tr: 持续的压力让他感到身心俱疲，毫无希望。

vocab.ex: The garden was filled with yellow primroses in early spring.
vocab.tr: 初春时，花园里开满了黄色的报春花。

vocab.mean: 至少他们是这么告诉我的（表示不确定或信息来自他人）
vocab.ex: This is supposed to be the best restaurant in town, or so they tell me.
vocab.tr: 据说这是城里最好的餐厅，至少他们是这么告诉我的。

gram.name: 明喻 (as... as...)
gram.pattern: as + adjective + as + noun
gram.function: 用于将一事物的某种品质与另一事物进行直接比较，以创造生动的形象。'as fresh as a raindrop, as lovely as the primrose' 两个并列的明喻，突出了Prim的纯洁与美好，与周围严酷的环境形成对比。

example.en: His eyes were as blue as the summer sky.
example.tr: 他的眼睛像夏日的天空一样湛蓝。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的描述性语言。

paras.en: Sitting at Prim’s knees, guarding her, is the world’s ugliest cat. Mashed-in nose, half of one ear missing, eyes the color of rotting squash. Prim named him Buttercup, insisting that his muddy yellow coat matched the bright flower. He hates me. Or at least distrusts me. Even though it was years ago, I think he still remembers how I tried to drown him in a bucket when Prim brought him home. Scrawny kitten, belly swollen with worms, crawling with fleas. The last thing I needed was another mouth to feed. But Prim begged so hard, cried even, I had to let him stay. It turned out okay. My mother got rid of the vermin and he’s a born mouser. Even catches the occasional rat. Sometimes, when I clean a kill, I feed Buttercup the entrails. He has stopped hissing at me. Entrails. No hissing. This is the closest we will ever come to love.
paras.cn: 坐在波丽姆膝边守护着她的是世界上最丑的猫。塌鼻子，一只耳朵少了一半，眼睛是腐烂南瓜的颜色。波丽姆给他取名毛茛花，坚持说他那泥黄色的毛皮和那种鲜艳的花很配。他恨我。或者至少不信任我。尽管那是多年前的事了，我想他仍然记得当波丽姆把他带回家时，我曾试图把他淹死在水桶里。一只瘦骨嶙峋的小猫，肚子因生虫而肿胀，爬满了跳蚤。我最不需要的就是又多一张要喂的嘴。但波丽姆苦苦哀求，甚至哭了，我不得不让他留下来。结果还不错。我母亲除掉了寄生虫，而且他是个天生的捕鼠能手。甚至偶尔能抓到老鼠。有时候，当我处理猎物时，我会把内脏喂给毛茛花。他已经不再对我嘶嘶叫了。内脏。不嘶嘶叫。这是我们所能达到的最接近爱的状态了。

vocab.ex: The front of the car was completely mashed-in after the accident.
vocab.tr: 事故之后，车的前部完全塌陷了。

vocab.ex: There was a smell of rotting fruit coming from the garbage can.
vocab.tr: 垃圾桶里传来一股腐烂水果的味道。

vocab.ex: For dinner, we're having roasted squash with herbs.
vocab.tr: 晚餐我们吃香草烤南瓜。

vocab.ex: The stray cat was scrawny and looked like it hadn't eaten in days.
vocab.tr: 那只流浪猫瘦骨嶙峋，看起来好像好几天没吃东西了。

vocab.ex: His ankle was swollen and painful after the fall.
vocab.tr: 摔倒后，他的脚踝又肿又痛。

vocab.ex: The old barn was infested with rats and other vermin.
vocab.tr: 那个旧谷仓里满是老鼠和其他害虫。

vocab.ex: Our new cat turned out to be an excellent mouser.
vocab.tr: 我们的新猫原来是个出色的捕鼠能手。

vocab.ex: In ancient Rome, priests would read the future in the entrails of sacrificed animals.
vocab.tr: 在古罗马，牧师会通过被献祭动物的内脏来预测未来。

vocab.ex: The cat started to hiss at the strange dog.
vocab.tr: 那只猫开始对着陌生的狗发出嘶嘶声。

gram.name: 用于营造愤世嫉俗语调的句子片段
gram.pattern: A series of noun phrases used as complete sentences.
gram.function: 通过使用一系列简短、断续的句子片段（'Scrawny kitten...', 'Entrails. No hissing.'），作者创造了一种粗粝、不带感情的叙事节奏。这种手法模仿了快速的回忆闪现，并最终通过 'This is the closest we will ever come to love.' 这个愤世嫉俗的结论，深刻地揭示了主角在严酷环境中形成的务实、冷峻的世界观。

example.en: Cold coffee. A rainy Monday. Another week begins.
example.tr: 冷咖啡。一个下雨的周一。又一周开始了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过句法来塑造人物性格和语气的文学技巧。

paras.en: I swing my legs off the bed and slide into my hunting boots. Supple leather that has molded to my feet. I pull on trousers, a shirt, tuck my long dark braid up into a cap, and grab my forage bag. On the table, under a wooden bowl to protect it from hungry rats and cats alike, sits a perfect little goat cheese wrapped in basil leaves. Prim’s gift to me on reaping day. I put the cheese carefully in my pocket as I slip outside.
paras.cn: 我把腿从床上甩下来，滑进我的猎靴。柔软的皮革已经完全贴合我的脚型。我穿上裤子、衬衫，把我的深色长辫子塞进帽子里，然后抓起我的觅食袋。桌上，一个木碗下放着一块用罗勒叶包裹着的完美的小山羊奶酪，以保护它免受饥饿的老鼠和猫的侵扰。这是波丽姆在收获日给我的礼物。我小心地把奶酪放进口袋，溜了出去。

vocab.ex: After years of use, the leather jacket had become soft and supple.
vocab.tr: 经过多年的使用，这件皮夹克变得柔软而柔韧。

vocab.ex: A good pair of running shoes will mold to the shape of your feet.
vocab.tr: 一双好的跑鞋会贴合你的脚型。

vocab.ex: Please tuck your shirt into your trousers.
vocab.tr: 请把你的衬衫塞进裤子里。

vocab.ex: She went into the woods with her forage bag to look for mushrooms.
vocab.tr: 她带着她的觅食袋进入树林寻找蘑菇。

vocab.ex: The new law applies to both rich and poor alike.
vocab.tr: 新法律同样适用于富人和穷人。

vocab.ex: She added some fresh basil to the tomato sauce.
vocab.tr: 她在番茄酱里加了一些新鲜的罗勒。

gram.name: 用于描述的句子片段
gram.pattern: A series of noun phrases used as complete sentences.
gram.function: 通过使用名词短语作为独立的句子（'Supple leather that has molded to my feet.' 和 'Prim’s gift to me on reaping day.'），作者创造了一种专注、注重细节的叙事节奏。这些片段就像是主角脑海中闪过的特写镜头，强调了这些物品对她的重要性和意义。

example.en: He looked around the room. A dusty desk. An empty chair. A single photograph on the wall.
example.tr: 他环顾房间。一张布满灰尘的书桌。一把空椅子。墙上一张孤零零的照片。

gram.constraints: 是一种在文学描述中常见的技巧。

paras.en: Our part of District 12, nicknamed the Seam, is usually crawling with coal miners heading out to the morning shift at this hour. Men and women with hunched shoulders, swollen knuckles, many who have long since stopped trying to scrub the coal dust out of their broken nails, the lines of their sunken faces. But today the black cinder streets are empty. Shutters on the squat gray houses are closed. The reaping isn’t until two. May as well sleep in. If you can.
paras.cn: 我们居住的第12区，绰号“夹缝地带”，在这个时辰通常爬满了前往早班的煤矿工人。男男女女都弓着背，关节肿大，许多人早已放弃擦洗嵌在破裂指甲里和凹陷脸庞纹路中的煤灰。但今天，黑色的煤渣街道空无一人。矮胖的灰色房子上的百叶窗都关着。收获日要到两点才开始。不妨睡个懒觉。如果你能睡得着的话。

vocab.ex: His friends nicknamed him 'Shorty' because he was so tall.
vocab.tr: 他的朋友们给他起了个“矮子”的绰号，因为他长得很高。

vocab.ex: The kitchen was crawling with ants.
vocab.tr: 厨房里爬满了蚂蚁。

vocab.ex: He works the night shift at the factory.
vocab.tr: 他在工厂上夜班。

vocab.ex: The old man walked with hunched shoulders.
vocab.tr: 那位老人弓着背走路。

vocab.ex: After weeks of illness, her eyes looked tired and sunken.
vocab.tr: 经过数周的病痛，她的眼睛看起来疲惫而凹陷。

vocab.ex: The path was covered with dark cinder.
vocab.tr: 小路上覆盖着黑色的煤渣。

vocab.ex: He lived in a small, squat cottage by the sea.
vocab.tr: 他住在海边一栋矮胖的小屋里。

vocab.ex: Since it's raining, we may as well stay inside and watch a movie.
vocab.tr: 既然下雨了，我们不妨待在室内看场电影。

gram.name: 用于描述的同位语短语
gram.pattern: Noun, + a long descriptive phrase.
gram.function: 使用一个非常长的、由多个名词短语和定语从句构成的同位语短语（'Men and women with hunched shoulders...'），来详细地描绘和定义前面的名词 'coal miners'。这种结构通过堆叠意象，深刻地刻画了矿工们被艰苦生活所磨损的集体形象。

example.en: He was a true artist, a man who saw beauty in the mundane, who could turn simple clay into a masterpiece.
example.tr: 他是一位真正的艺术家，一个能在平凡中看到美的人，一个能将普通黏土变成杰作的人。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过补充说明来丰富核心名词内涵的有效方式。

paras.en: Our house is almost at the edge of the Seam. I only have to pass a few gates to reach the scruffy field called the Meadow. Separating the Meadow from the woods, in fact enclosing all of District 12, is a high chain-link fence topped with barbed-wire loops. In theory, it’s supposed to be electrified twenty-four hours a day as a deterrent to the predators that live in the woods — packs of wild dogs, lone cougars, bears — that used to threaten our streets. But since we’re lucky to get two or three hours of electricity in the evenings, it’s usually safe to touch. Even so, I always take a moment to listen carefully for the hum that means the fence is live. Right now, it’s silent as a stone. Concealed by a clump of bushes, I flatten out on my belly and slide under a two-foot stretch that’s been loose for years. There are several other weak spots in the fence, but this one is so close to home I almost always enter the woods here.
paras.cn: 我们的房子几乎在夹缝地带的边缘。我只需经过几道门就能到达那片叫做“牧场”的杂乱田野。将牧场与树林隔开，实际上是包围了整个第12区的，是一道高高的铁丝网围栏，顶部带有带刺的铁丝圈。理论上，它应该一天二十四小时通电，作为对生活在树林里的捕食者——成群的野狗、孤单的美洲狮、熊——的威慑，它们过去常常威胁我们的街道。但由于我们晚上能有两三个小时的电就已经很幸运了，所以触摸它通常是安全的。即便如此，我总是会花一点时间仔细听，听那表示围栏带电的嗡嗡声。现在，它静如磐石。我藏在一丛灌木后面，趴在肚子上，从一段松了好几年的两英尺宽的空隙下滑了过去。围栏上还有其他几个薄弱点，但这一个离家如此之近，我几乎总是在这里进入树林。

vocab.ex: A scruffy dog with matted fur was sleeping on the porch.
vocab.tr: 一只毛发打结的邋遢狗在门廊上睡觉。

vocab.ex: The playground was surrounded by a high chain-link fence.
vocab.tr: 操场被一道高高的铁丝网围栏包围着。

vocab.ex: The prison was surrounded by a tall fence topped with barbed-wire.
vocab.tr: 监狱被一道顶部装有带刺铁丝网的高墙包围着。

vocab.ex: The presence of security cameras acts as a deterrent to crime.
vocab.tr: 监控摄像头的存在对犯罪起到了威慑作用。

vocab.ex: The lion is a fierce predator at the top of the food chain.
vocab.tr: 狮子是处于食物链顶端的凶猛捕食者。

vocab.ex: I could hear the low hum of the refrigerator in the quiet kitchen.
vocab.tr: 在安静的厨房里，我能听到冰箱低沉的嗡嗡声。

vocab.ex: He tried to conceal the gift behind his back.
vocab.tr: 他试图把礼物藏在身后。

vocab.ex: A clump of wildflowers was growing by the side of the road.
vocab.tr: 路边长着一丛野花。

gram.name: 分词短语置于句首引起的倒装
gram.pattern: Participle Phrase + is/was + Subject.
gram.function: 将现在分词短语（'Separating the Meadow from the woods...' 和 'enclosing all of District 12'）置于句首，并将其后的主谓进行完全倒装（'is a high chain-link fence'），这是一种文学性的、用于强调和创造生动画面感的句型。

example.en: Standing at the top of the hill was a lone tree.
example.tr: 山顶上矗立着一棵孤零零的树。

gram.constraints: 只有当主语是名词时才倒装；如果主语是代词则不倒装。

paras.en: As soon as I’m in the trees, I retrieve a bow and sheath of arrows from a hollow log. Electrified or not, the fence has been successful at keeping the flesh-eaters out of District 12. Inside the woods they roam freely, and there are added concerns like venomous snakes, rabid animals, and no real paths to follow. But there’s also food if you know how to find it. My father knew and he taught me some before he was blown to bits in a mine explosion. There was nothing even to bury. I was eleven then. Five years later, I still wake up screaming for him to run.
paras.cn: 我一进树林，就从一根空心圆木里取出一张弓和一鞘箭。不管通不通电，围栏都成功地将食肉动物挡在了第12区之外。在树林里，它们自由地漫步，而且还有额外的担忧，比如毒蛇、狂犬病动物，以及没有真正的路可走。但如果你知道如何寻找，那里也有食物。我父亲知道，在他被一次矿井爆炸炸成碎片之前，他教过我一些。甚至没有什么东西可以埋葬。那时我十一岁。五年后，我仍然会尖叫着惊醒，让他快跑。

vocab.ex: He had to go back to retrieve the wallet he had left on the table.
vocab.tr: 他得回去取回他落在桌上的钱包。

vocab.ex: The archer pulled an arrow from the sheath on his back.
vocab.tr: 弓箭手从他背上的箭鞘里抽出一支箭。

vocab.ex: The bird made its nest inside a hollow tree.
vocab.tr: 那只鸟在一棵空心树里筑了巢。

vocab.ex: Wild horses still roam freely in that remote valley.
vocab.tr: 野马仍然在那个偏远的山谷里自由地漫步。

vocab.ex: Be careful when hiking; some of the snakes in this area are venomous.
vocab.tr: 徒步时要小心；这个地区有些蛇是有毒的。

vocab.ex: A bite from a rabid animal can be fatal if not treated immediately.
vocab.tr: 如果不及早治疗，被患狂犬病的动物咬伤可能是致命的。

vocab.ex: The old building was blown to bits in the controlled demolition.
vocab.tr: 那座旧楼在受控爆破中被炸成了碎片。

gram.name: 用于表现创伤的简短陈述句
gram.pattern: A series of short, impactful sentences.
gram.function: 在描述完父亲的死亡后，作者使用了一连串非常简短、客观且不带感情的句子（'There was nothing even to bury. I was eleven then. Five years later...'）。这种简洁、克制的叙述方式，与事件本身的巨大悲剧性形成鲜明对比，反而更能突显创伤的深刻和持久，比华丽的辞藻更具冲击力。

example.en: The fire took everything. Nothing was left. She was all alone.
example.tr: 大火夺走了一切。什么也没留下。她孤身一人。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过克制来增强情感力量的文学技巧。

paras.en: Even though trespassing in the woods is illegal and poaching carries the severest of penalties, more people would risk it if they had weapons. But most are not bold enough to venture out with just a knife. My bow is a rarity, crafted by my father along with a few others that I keep well hidden in the woods, carefully wrapped in waterproof covers. My father could have made good money selling them, but if the officials found out he would have been publicly executed for inciting a rebellion. Most of the Peacekeepers turn a blind eye to the few of us who hunt because they’re as hungry for fresh meat as anybody is. In fact, they’re among our best customers. But the idea that someone might be arming the Seam would never have been allowed.
paras.cn: 尽管非法侵入树林是违法的，偷猎会受到最严厉的惩罚，但如果人们有武器，会有更多人去冒险。但大多数人没有足够的胆量只带一把刀就出去闯。我的弓是件稀罕物，是我父亲制作的，还有几张其他的弓，我把它们都好好地藏在树林里，用防水罩仔细包裹着。我父亲本可以靠卖弓赚大钱，但如果被官员发现，他会因为煽动叛乱而被公开处决。大多数维安人员对我们这些少数打猎的人都睁一只眼闭一只眼，因为他们和任何人一样渴望新鲜的肉。事实上，他们是我们最好的顾客之一。但是有人可能在武装夹缝地带这种想法是绝不会被允许的。

vocab.ex: He was arrested for trespassing on private property.
vocab.tr: 他因非法侵入私人财产而被捕。

vocab.ex: Stricter laws were introduced to combat poaching of endangered animals.
vocab.tr: 为打击偷猎濒危动物，出台了更严格的法律。

vocab.ex: The penalty for speeding is a hefty fine.
vocab.tr: 超速的惩罚是高额罚款。

vocab.ex: Few people dared to venture out during the blizzard.
vocab.tr: 暴风雪期间，很少有人敢冒险外出。

vocab.ex: In this desert climate, rainfall is a rarity.
vocab.tr: 在这种沙漠气候下，降雨是件稀罕事。

vocab.ex: He was accused of using his speeches to incite a rebellion against the government.
vocab.tr: 他被指控用他的演讲煽动反对政府的叛乱。

vocab.ex: The teacher decided to turn a blind eye to the student's minor mistake.
vocab.tr: 老师决定对学生的那个小错误睁一只眼闭一只眼。

gram.name: 第三条件句（用于未实现的过去）
gram.pattern: could have + pp..., but if..., ...would have been + pp
gram.function: 用于描述与过去事实相反的假设情况及其可能的结果。'My father could have made good money..., but if the officials found out he would have been publicly executed...' 这一组句子，先提出了一个未实现的过去的可能性，然后用一个第三条件句解释了为什么这个可能性没有发生，并描绘了其可怕的虚拟后果。

example.en: I could have gone to the party, but if I had gone, I would have missed my flight.
example.tr: 我本可以去参加派对的，但如果我去了，我就会错过我的航班。

gram.constraints: 用于对过去情况的虚拟假设。

paras.en: In the fall, a few brave souls sneak into the woods to harvest apples. But always in sight of the Meadow. Always close enough to run back to the safety of District 12 if trouble arises. “District Twelve. Where you can starve to death in safety,” I mutter. Then I glance quickly over my shoulder. Even here, even in the middle of nowhere, you worry someone might overhear you.
paras.cn: 秋天，一些勇敢的人会溜进树林里收获苹果。但总是在能看到牧场的地方。总是在离得足够近，以便一旦有麻烦就能跑回第12区的安全地带。“第十二区。一个你可以安全地饿死的地方，” 我咕哝道。然后我迅速地回头看了一眼。即使在这里，即使在荒无人烟的地方，你也会担心有人可能会偷听到你。

vocab.ex: Only a few brave souls dared to swim in the icy water.
vocab.tr: 只有几个勇敢的人敢在冰冷的水中游泳。

vocab.ex: He tried to sneak into the movie theater without a ticket.
vocab.tr: 他试图不买票溜进电影院。

vocab.ex: It's time to harvest the corn from the fields.
vocab.tr: 是时候从田里收获玉米了。

vocab.ex: They built their house in sight of the ocean.
vocab.tr: 他们把房子建在能看见海的地方。

vocab.ex: If any problems arise, please contact me immediately.
vocab.tr: 如果出现任何问题，请立即联系我。

vocab.ex: He was muttering to himself as he worked.
vocab.tr: 他工作时自言自语地咕哝着。

vocab.ex: Their car broke down in the middle of nowhere.
vocab.tr: 他们的车在荒无人烟的地方抛锚了。

vocab.ex: I happened to overhear their conversation about the secret party.
vocab.tr: 我碰巧无意中听到了他们关于秘密派对的谈话。

gram.name: 反讽与悖论
gram.pattern: Juxtaposing two contradictory concepts.
gram.function: 句子 'District Twelve. Where you can starve to death in safety' 是一个典型的反讽和悖论。它将“安全”（safety）和“饿死”（starve to death）这两个本应相互排斥的概念并置在一起，深刻地揭示了第12区生存状态的荒谬和悲惨：一种有保障的、缓慢的死亡。

example.en: The silence in the room was deafening.
example.tr: 房间里的寂静震耳欲聋。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过矛盾来揭示深层真相的修辞手法。

paras.en: When I was younger, I scared my mother to death, the things I would blurt out about District 12, about the people who rule our country, Panem, from the far-off city called the Capitol. Eventually I understood this would only lead us to more trouble. So I learned to hold my tongue and to turn my features into an indifferent mask so that no one could ever read my thoughts. Do my work quietly in school. Make only polite small talk in the public market. Discuss little more than trades in the Hob, which is the black market where I make most of my money. Even at home, where I am less pleasant, I avoid discussing tricky topics. Like the reaping, or food shortages, or the Hunger Games. Prim might begin to repeat my words and then where would we be?
paras.cn: 我年轻时，我说的那些关于第12区、关于从遥远的“国会区”统治我们国家帕纳姆的人的话，把我妈妈吓得要死。最终我明白了这只会给我们带来更多麻烦。所以我学会了管住我的舌头，把我的表情变成一张冷漠的面具，这样就没人能读懂我的想法。在学校里安静地做我的事。在公共市场上只进行礼貌的闲聊。在“黑市”（The Hob）——我大部分钱的来源地——只谈论些交易。即使在家里，我没那么愉快，我也会避免讨论棘手的话题。比如收获日，或者食物短缺，或者饥饿游戏。波丽姆可能会开始重复我的话，那我们该怎么办呢？

vocab.ex: The sudden loud noise scared me to death.
vocab.tr: 那突如其来的巨响把我吓得要死。

vocab.ex: In a moment of panic, he blurted out the secret.
vocab.tr: 在恐慌的一瞬间，他脱口说出了秘密。

vocab.ex: She dreamed of traveling to far-off lands.
vocab.tr: 她梦想着去遥远的国度旅行。

vocab.ex: I wanted to say what I really thought, but I decided to hold my tongue.
vocab.tr: 我想说出我的真实想法，但我决定保持沉默。

vocab.ex: He seemed indifferent to the suffering of others.
vocab.tr: 他对别人的痛苦似乎漠不关心。

vocab.ex: I'm not very good at making small talk at parties.
vocab.tr: 我不太擅长在派对上闲聊。

vocab.ex: During the war, many goods were only available on the black market.
vocab.tr: 战争期间，许多商品只能在黑市上买到。

vocab.ex: This is a tricky problem that requires careful thought.
vocab.tr: 这是一个需要仔细思考的棘手问题。

gram.name: 用于描述策略的平行不定式
gram.pattern: learn to [action 1] and to [action 2]...
gram.function: 通过一系列并列的不定式或动词原形（'to hold my tongue', 'to turn my features...', 'Do my work...', 'Make only polite small talk...', 'Discuss little more...'），作者清晰地列举了主角为了生存而学会的一套自我保护策略。这种平行结构有力地展示了她在压抑环境下的生存之道。

example.en: To succeed, you must learn to listen, to be patient, and to work hard.
example.tr: 要成功，你必须学会倾听、有耐心和努力工作。

gram.constraints: 是一种清晰地列举步骤或策略的有效方式。

paras.en: In the woods waits the only person with whom I can be myself. Gale. I can feel the muscles in my face relaxing, my pace quickening as I climb the hills to our place, a rock ledge overlooking a valley. A thicket of berry bushes protects it from unwanted eyes. The sight of him waiting there brings on a smile. Gale says I never smile except in the woods.
paras.cn: 树林里等待着唯一一个能让我做自己的人。盖尔。我能感觉到我脸上的肌肉在放松，当我爬上山坡去我们的地方时，我的步伐加快了。那是一个可以俯瞰山谷的岩架。一丛浓密的浆果灌木保护它免受不必要的目光。看到他在那里等着的情景，让我露出了微笑。盖尔说我除了在树林里，从不微笑。

vocab.ex: With my closest friends, I feel free to be myself.
vocab.tr: 和我最亲密的朋友在一起时，我感到可以自由地做我自己。

vocab.ex: He walked at a slow, steady pace.
vocab.tr: 他以缓慢而稳定的步伐行走。

vocab.ex: His heart rate began to quicken as he ran faster.
vocab.tr: 随着他跑得更快，他的心率开始加快。

vocab.ex: A mountain goat stood on a narrow ledge high above us.
vocab.tr: 一只山羊站在我们上方高处一个狭窄的岩架上。

vocab.ex: Our hotel room balcony overlooks the ocean.
vocab.tr: 我们酒店房间的阳台可以俯瞰大海。

vocab.ex: The rabbit disappeared into a thicket of bushes.
vocab.tr: 兔子消失在一片灌木丛中。

paras.en: “Hey, Catnip,” says Gale. My real name is Katniss, but when I first told him, I had barely whispered it. So he thought I’d said Catnip. Then when this crazy lynx started following me around the woods looking for handouts, it became his official nickname for me. I finally had to kill the lynx because he scared off game. I almost regretted it because he wasn’t bad company. But I got a decent price for his pelt.
paras.cn: “嘿，猫薄荷，” 盖尔说。我的真名是凯特尼斯，但我第一次告诉他时，我几乎是低声说的。所以他以为我说的是猫薄荷。后来当这只疯狂的山猫开始在树林里跟着我讨要食物时，这就成了他给我的正式绰号。我最后不得不杀了那只山猫，因为它吓跑了猎物。我差点就后悔了，因为它不是个坏伙伴。但我它的毛皮卖了个不错的价钱。

vocab.ex: My cat goes crazy for catnip.
vocab.tr: 我的猫对猫薄荷很疯狂。

vocab.ex: The room was so dark I could barely see anything.
vocab.tr: 房间太黑了，我几乎什么也看不见。

vocab.ex: The Canada lynx is known for its large paws that act like snowshoes.
vocab.tr: 加拿大山猫以其像雪鞋一样的大爪子而闻名。

vocab.ex: The homeless man was grateful for the handout of a warm meal.
vocab.tr: 那个无家可归的人对施舍的一顿热饭心存感激。

vocab.ex: The loud noise from the car scared off the birds.
vocab.tr: 汽车的巨响吓跑了鸟儿。

vocab.ex: The hunters returned to the camp with their game.
vocab.tr: 猎人们带着他们的猎物回到了营地。

vocab.ex: I deeply regret my decision to quit the team.
vocab.tr: 我深深地后悔我退出队伍的决定。

vocab.ex: The trader sold the valuable beaver pelt at the market.
vocab.tr: 商人在市场上出售了那张珍贵的海狸皮。

gram.name: 情感与实用主义的并置
gram.pattern: An emotional statement followed immediately by a practical one.
gram.function: 叙述者首先表达了对杀死山猫的一丝情感和后悔（'I almost regretted it because he wasn’t bad company.'），然后立即用一个非常务实的陈述（'But I got a decent price for his pelt.'）来结束。这种情感与实用主义的快速切换和并置，深刻地揭示了主角在严酷生存环境中所形成的性格：她有情感，但生存的需要永远是第一位的。

example.en: He loved his old car, but he sold it for a good price to pay his rent.
example.tr: 他爱他的旧车，但他为了付房租把它卖了个好价钱。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比来塑造人物性格和揭示其价值观的有效技巧。

paras.en: “Look what I shot,” Gale holds up a loaf of bread with an arrow stuck in it, and I laugh. It’s real bakery bread, not the flat, dense loaves we make from our grain rations. I take it in my hands, pull out the arrow, and hold the puncture in the crust to my nose, inhaling the fragrance that makes my mouth flood with saliva. Fine bread like this is for special occasions.
paras.cn: “看我射中了什么，” 盖尔举起一块插着箭的面包，我笑了。这是真正的面包店面包，不是我们用配给的谷物做的那种又扁又实的面包。我把它拿到手里，拔出箭，把面包皮上的穿孔凑到鼻子上，吸入那让我的嘴里充满唾液的香味。像这样好的面包是为特殊场合准备的。

vocab.ex: She held up her hand to ask a question.
vocab.tr: 她举起手来提问。

vocab.ex: Could you buy a loaf of bread from the store?
vocab.tr: 你能从商店买一条面包吗？

vocab.ex: This cake is very rich and dense.
vocab.tr: 这个蛋糕非常浓郁和密实。

vocab.ex: During the war, each family received a weekly ration of sugar.
vocab.tr: 战争期间，每个家庭每周都能领到一份糖的配给。

vocab.ex: A nail on the road caused a puncture in my tire.
vocab.tr: 路上的钉子在我的轮胎上扎了个孔。

vocab.ex: Take a deep breath and inhale the fresh mountain air.
vocab.tr: 深呼吸，吸入新鲜的山间空气。

vocab.ex: The smell of baking bread made his mouth fill with saliva.
vocab.tr: 烤面包的香味让他的嘴里充满了唾液。

gram.name: 用于表达珍视的感官语言
gram.pattern: Using detailed sensory descriptions to show value.
gram.function: 作者没有直接说“面包很珍贵”，而是通过一连串详细的感官描写来展示——视觉对比（'real bakery bread, not the flat, dense loaves'）、触觉（'take it in my hands'）、嗅觉（'inhaling the fragrance'）和生理反应（'makes my mouth flood with saliva'）。这种“展示而非告知”的技巧，让读者能切身感受到面包的珍贵和主角的渴望。

example.en: She described the peach: the soft fuzz on its skin, the sweet smell, the way the juice dripped down her chin.
example.tr: 她描述着那个桃子：皮上的软毛，甜美的香气，以及果汁顺着她下巴滴下的样子。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过具体感官体验来传达抽象价值的写作技巧。

paras.en: “Mm, still warm,” I say. He must have been at the bakery at the crack of dawn to trade for it. “What did it cost you?” “Just a squirrel. Think the old man was feeling sentimental this morning,” says Gale. “Even wished me luck.” “Well, we all feel a little closer today, don’t we?” I say, not even bothering to roll my eyes. “Prim left us a cheese.” I pull it out.
paras.cn: “嗯，还热着呢，” 我说。他肯定是在天一亮就去了面包店换来的。“花了你什么？” “只是一只松鼠。想必那老头今天早上多愁善感了，” 盖尔说。“甚至还祝我好运。” “嗯，我们今天都感觉亲近了一点，不是吗？” 我说，甚至都懒得翻白眼。“波丽姆给我们留了块奶酪。” 我把它拿了出来。

vocab.ex: The farmers wake up at the crack of dawn to start their work.
vocab.tr: 农夫们天一亮就起床开始干活了。

vocab.ex: He decided to trade his old car for a new motorcycle.
vocab.tr: 他决定用他的旧车换一辆新摩托车。

vocab.ex: She gets sentimental whenever she looks at old family photos.
vocab.tr: 每当看旧的家庭照片时，她都会变得多愁善感。

vocab.ex: He didn't even bother to say goodbye before he left.
vocab.tr: 他离开前甚至都懒得说声再见。

vocab.mean: 翻白眼（表示不耐烦或不屑）
vocab.ex: She rolled her eyes when her brother started telling another one of his boring stories.
vocab.tr: 当她哥哥又开始讲他那些无聊的故事时，她翻了个白眼。

gram.name: 情态动词推测 (must have been)
gram.pattern: must have + past participle
gram.function: 用于对过去发生的事情进行非常肯定的推测或推断。'He must have been at the bakery...' 表达了主角根据面包“还热着”这个证据，对盖尔的行为做出的强烈推断。

example.en: The ground is wet. It must have rained last night.
example.tr: 地面是湿的。昨晚肯定下雨了。

gram.constraints: 只用于对过去事件的推测。

paras.en: His expression brightens at the treat. “Thank you, Prim. We’ll have a real feast.” Suddenly he falls into a Capitol accent as he mimics Effie Trinket, the maniacally upbeat woman who arrives once a year to read out the names at the leaping. “I almost forgot! Happy Hunger Games!” He plucks a few blackberries from the bushes around us. “And may the odds —” He tosses a berry in a high arc toward me. I catch it in my mouth and break the delicate skin with my teeth. The sweet tartness explodes across my tongue. “— be ever in your favor!” I finish with equal verve. We have to joke about it because the alternative is to be scared out of your wits. Besides, the Capitol accent is so affected, almost anything sounds funny in it.
paras.cn: 看到这份美食，他的表情亮了起来。“谢谢你，波丽姆。我们能大餐一顿了。” 他突然换上国会区的口音，模仿起埃菲·特林켓，那个每年一次来宣读名字的、狂热乐观的女人。“我差点忘了！饥饿游戏快乐！” 他从我们周围的灌木丛中摘下几颗黑莓。“愿几率——” 他把一颗莓果朝我高高抛来。我用嘴接住它，用牙齿咬破它娇嫩的表皮。那股甜酸味在我舌尖上爆炸开来。“——永远对你有利！” 我用同样的热情完成了这句话。我们必须拿它开玩笑，因为另一个选择就是被吓得魂飞魄散。此外，国会区的口音太做作了，几乎任何话用那种口音说出来都听起来很滑稽。

vocab.ex: Her face brightened when she saw the surprise gift.
vocab.tr: 当她看到惊喜礼物时，她的脸一下子亮了起来。

vocab.ex: The king prepared a great feast for the visiting nobles.
vocab.tr: 国王为来访的贵族准备了盛大的宴会。

vocab.ex: The comedian was famous for his ability to mimic politicians' voices.
vocab.tr: 那位喜剧演员以模仿政治家声音的能力而闻名。

vocab.ex: He was laughing maniacally at his own evil plan.
vocab.tr: 他对着自己邪恶的计划狂笑不止。

vocab.ex: Despite the challenges, she maintained an upbeat attitude.
vocab.tr: 尽管面临挑战，她仍保持着乐观的态度。

vocab.ex: The basketball flew in a perfect arc and went straight through the hoop.
vocab.tr: 篮球在空中划出一道完美的弧线，径直穿过篮筐。

vocab.ex: She performed the dance with great energy and verve.
vocab.tr: 她以极大的精力和热情表演了那支舞。

vocab.word: be scared out of one's wits
vocab.ex: The sudden loud bang scared me out of my wits.
vocab.tr: 那声突如其来的巨响把我吓得魂飞魄散。

vocab.ex: She spoke in an affected high-pitched voice to sound more elegant.
vocab.tr: 她用一种做作的高音说话，好让声音听起来更优雅。

gram.name: 应对机制（幽默）
gram.pattern: Using humor to deal with a terrifying situation.
gram.function: 作者通过 'We have to joke about it because the alternative is to be scared out of your wits.' 这句话，明确地指出了幽默在这里的功能：它不是纯粹的娱乐，而是一种应对恐惧和无力感的心理防御机制。通过模仿和嘲弄压迫者的语言，他们在心理上获得了一丝控制感。

example.en: They made dark jokes about the dangerous situation; it was their only way to cope.
example.tr: 他们就危险的处境开着黑色玩笑；那是他们唯一的应对方式。

gram.constraints: 是一种揭示角色心理韧性和生存策略的深刻洞察。

paras.en: I watch as Gale pulls out his knife and slices the bread. He could be my brother. Straight black hair, olive skin, we even have the same gray eyes. But we’re not related, at least not closely. Most of the families who work the mines resemble one another this way. That’s why my mother and Prim, with their light hair and blue eyes, always look out of place. They are. My mother’s parents were part of the small merchant class that caters to officials, Peacekeepers, and the occasional Seam customer. They ran an apothecary shop in the nicer part of District 12. Since almost no one can afford doctors, apothecaries are our healers. My father got to know my mother because on his hunts he would sometimes collect medicinal herbs and sell them to her shop to be brewed into remedies. She must have really loved him to leave her home for the Seam. I try to remember that when all I can see is the woman who sat by, blank and unreachable, while her children turned to skin and bones. I try to forgive her for my father’s sake. But to be honest, I’m not the forgiving type.
paras.cn: 我看着盖尔拿出他的刀，切着面包。他可能是我的兄弟。笔直的黑发，橄榄色的皮肤，我们甚至有同样的灰色眼睛。但我们没有血缘关系，至少不是近亲。大多数在矿上工作的家庭都长得这样彼此相似。这就是为什么我母亲和波丽姆，她们浅色的头发和蓝色的眼睛，总显得格格不入。她们确实是。我母亲的父母是小商人阶层的一员，为官员、维安人员和偶尔的夹缝地带顾客服务。他们在第12区较好的地段经营一家药店。由于几乎没人看得起医生，药剂师就是我们的治疗师。我父亲认识我母亲是因为他在打猎时有时会采集草药，卖给她的店里熬制成药。她一定是真的爱他，才会离开家来到夹缝地带。当我眼中只剩下那个在孩子们瘦成皮包骨时，却呆坐在一旁、表情空白、遥不可及的女人时，我努力记住这一点。我为了我父亲而努力原谅她。但说实话，我不是那种宽宏大量的人。

vocab.ex: I just found out that we are distantly related through my grandmother.
vocab.tr: 我刚发现我们通过我祖母有远亲关系。

vocab.tr: 她和她母亲在那个年纪时非常相像。

vocab.ex: With his bright suit at the somber funeral, he looked completely out of place.
vocab.tr: 在肃穆的葬礼上，他穿着鲜艳的西装，显得格格不入。

vocab.ex: The hotel caters to business travelers with its excellent conference facilities.
vocab.tr: 该酒店以其卓越的会议设施来迎合商务旅客的需求。

vocab.ex: In the historical village, there was a recreated apothecary shop.
vocab.tr: 在那个历史村落里，有一家复原的旧式药店。

vocab.tr: 一杯加蜂蜜的热茶是治疗喉咙痛的好方法。

vocab.ex: He holds grudges for years; he's definitely not the forgiving type.
vocab.tr: 他会记仇好几年；他绝对不是那种宽宏大量的人。

gram.name: 对比的人物形象
gram.pattern: Juxtaposing a romanticized past with a harsh present reality.
gram.function: 叙述者将母亲过去浪漫的形象（'She must have really loved him to leave her home...'）与现在严酷的形象（'the woman who sat by, blank and unreachable...'）并置。这种强烈的对比，深刻地揭示了主角对母亲复杂的情感：她理解母亲过去的牺牲，但又无法原谅她现在的冷漠。这种矛盾是人物关系的核心。

example.en: I try to remember the vibrant young man he used to be, not the tired old man he has become.
example.tr: 我努力记住他过去那个充满活力的年轻人，而不是他现在这个疲惫的老人。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过时间对比来塑造复杂人物性格的文学技巧。

paras.en: Gale spreads the bread slices with the soft goat cheese, carefully placing a basil leaf on each while I strip the bushes of their berries. We settle back in a nook in the rocks. From this place, we are invisible but have a clear view of the valley, which is teeming with summer life, greens to gather, roots to dig, fish iridescent in the sunlight. The day is glorious, with a blue sky and soft breeze. The food’s wonderful, with the cheese seeping into the warm bread and the berries bursting in our mouths. Everything would be perfect if this really was a holiday, if all the day off meant was roaming the mountains with Gale, hunting for tonight’s supper. But instead we have to be standing in the square at two o’clock waiting for the names to be called out.
paras.cn: 盖尔把软山羊奶酪涂在面包片上，小心地在每片上放上一片罗勒叶，而我则剥光了灌木丛上的浆果。我们在岩石的一个角落里安顿下来。从这个地方，我们是隐形的，但能清楚地看到山谷，那里充满了夏日的生机，有可以采集的绿叶蔬菜，可以挖掘的根茎，还有在阳光下闪着彩虹色光芒的鱼。天气辉煌，蓝天白云，微风和煦。食物很美味，奶酪渗入温热的面包，浆果在我们口中爆开。如果这真的是一个假日，如果这天的休息只意味着和盖尔在山中漫步，为今晚的晚餐打猎，那么一切都会是完美的。但相反，我们必须在两点钟站在广场上，等待名字被叫出。

vocab.ex: She found a quiet nook in the library to read her book.
vocab.tr: 她在图书馆里找到了一个安静的角落来看书。

vocab.ex: The river was teeming with fish.
vocab.tr: 那条河里充满了鱼。

vocab.ex: The soap bubble had an iridescent sheen in the sunlight.
vocab.tr: 肥皂泡在阳光下呈现出彩虹色的光泽。

vocab.ex: It was a glorious day for a wedding.
vocab.tr: 那是一个举行婚礼的极好日子。

vocab.ex: Water started to seep into the basement through a crack in the wall.
vocab.tr: 水开始通过墙上的一道裂缝渗入地下室。

vocab.ex: He squeezed the water balloon until it burst.
vocab.tr: 他挤压水气球，直到它爆裂。

gram.name: 第二条件句（用于与现在事实相反的假设）
gram.pattern: Everything would be [adj] if + past simple.
gram.function: 用于描述一个与现在事实相反的、理想化的假设情境。'...Everything would be perfect if this really was a holiday...' 强调了当前这个美好时刻与残酷现实之间的巨大差距。这个虚拟语气深刻地揭示了他们短暂的幸福是建立在一个痛苦的现实之上的。

example.en: My life would be easier if I lived closer to work.
example.tr: 如果我住得离工作地点近一些，我的生活会更轻松。

gram.constraints: 条件从句用一般过去时，主句用 'would/could/might + 动词原形'。

paras.en: “We could do it, you know,” Gale says quietly. “What?” I ask. “Leave the district. Run off. Live in the woods. You and I, we could make it,” says Gale. I don’t know how to respond. The idea is so preposterous. “If we didn’t have so many kids,” he adds quickly. They’re not our kids, of course. But they might as well be. Gale’s two little brothers and a sister. Prim. And you may as well throw in our mothers, too, because how would they live without us? Who would fill those mouths that are always asking for more? With both of us hunting daily, there are still nights when game has to be swapped for lard or shoelaces or wool, still nights when we go to bed with our stomachs growling.
paras.cn: “我们可以做到，你知道的，” 盖尔轻声说。“什么？” 我问。“离开这个区。逃走。住在树林里。你和我，我们能活下去的，” 盖尔说。我不知道如何回应。这个想法太荒谬了。“如果我们没有这么多孩子的话，” 他迅速补充道。他们当然不是我们的孩子。但他们也差不多是了。盖尔的两个弟弟和一个妹妹。波丽姆。而且你也不妨把我们的妈妈也算上，因为没有我们她们怎么活？谁来填满那些总是索求更多的嘴？尽管我们俩每天都打猎，但仍然有夜晚需要用猎物换猪油、鞋带或羊毛，仍然有夜晚我们饿着肚子上床睡觉。

vocab.ex: The thief grabbed the purse and ran off.
vocab.tr: 小偷抓住钱包就跑了。

vocab.tr: 旅途很艰难，但他们还是成功到达了目的地。

vocab.ex: The idea that cats can fly is completely preposterous.
vocab.tr: 猫会飞这种想法完全是荒谬的。

vocab.ex: Since we're already wet from the rain, we might as well go for a swim.
vocab.tr: 既然我们已经被雨淋湿了，不妨就去游个泳吧。

vocab.tr: 我用我的巧克力棒换你那袋薯片。

vocab.tr: 过去，许多人用猪油而不是植物油做饭。

gram.name: 连接词省略（用于列举动作）
gram.pattern: A list of verbs or verb phrases without conjunctions.
gram.function: 盖尔通过一连串不使用连词的动词短语（'Leave the district. Run off. Live in the woods.'）来描述他的逃跑计划。这种连接词省略的手法，创造了一种快速、果断、充满希望的节奏，与主角犹豫不决的内心形成对比。

example.en: Wake up, get dressed, eat breakfast, go to work.
example.tr: 起床，穿衣，吃早饭，去上班。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过省略来增强节奏感和紧迫感的修辞技巧。

paras.en: “I never want to have kids,” I say. “I might. If I didn’t live here,” says Gale. “But you do,” I say, irritated. “Forget it,” he snaps back. The conversation feels all wrong. Leave? How could I leave Prim, who is the only person in the world I’m certain I love? And Gale is devoted to his family. We can’t leave, so why bother talking about it? And even if we did . . . even if we did . . . where did this stuff about having kids come from? There’s never been anything romantic between Gale and me. When we met, I was a skinny twelve-year-old, and although he was only two years older, he already looked like a man. It took a long time for us to even become friends, to stop haggling over every trade and begin helping each other out. Besides, if he wants kids, Gale won’t have any trouble finding a wife. He’s good-looking, he’s strong enough to handle the work in the mines, and he can hunt. You can tell by the way the girls whisper about him when he walks by in school that they want him. It makes me jealous but not for the reason people would think. Good hunting partners are hard to find.
paras.cn: “我永远不想生孩子，” 我说。“我也许会。如果我不住在这里的话，” 盖尔说。“但你确实住在这里，” 我说，有些恼火。“算了，” 他厉声回道。这场对话感觉全错了。离开？我怎么能离开波丽姆，她是我在这个世界上唯一确定我爱的人？而盖尔也对他的家庭尽心尽力。我们不能离开，那为什么还要费事谈论它呢？而且即使我们真的走了……即使我们真的走了……这关于生孩子的话题又是从哪儿来的？我和盖尔之间从来没有任何浪漫的成分。我们认识时，我还是个瘦小的十二岁女孩，尽管他只比我大两岁，他看起来已经像个男人了。我们花了很长时间才成为朋友，才停止为每一笔交易讨价还价，并开始互相帮助。此外，如果他想要孩子，盖尔找个妻子不会有任何困难。他长得好看，身体强壮到足以应付矿井的工作，而且他会打猎。从他在学校走过时女孩们对他窃窃私语的样子，你就能看出她们想要他。这让我嫉妒，但不是人们会想的那种原因。好的狩猎伙伴是很难找到的。

vocab.ex: She was clearly irritated by his constant interruptions.
vocab.tr: 她被他不停的打断惹得很恼火。

vocab.ex: When she criticized him, he snapped back with a rude comment.
vocab.tr: 当她批评他时，他用一句粗鲁的话回敬了她。

vocab.ex: He is a devoted father who would do anything for his children.

vocab.tr: 他们在日落时分去海滩进行了一次浪漫的散步。

vocab.tr: 他们花了二十分钟为那块旧地毯的价格讨价还价。

vocab.tr: 当他看到朋友有了一辆昂贵的新车时，他感到嫉妒。

gram.name: 通过否定进行澄清
gram.pattern: Statement + but not for the reason [one] would think.
gram.function: 在承认一种可能引起误解的情感（'It makes me jealous'）之后，叙述者立即用一个否定短语（'but not for the reason people would think'）来澄清这种情感的真实来源。这种结构显示了角色对自己内心世界的深刻洞察，以及她与传统情感模式（浪漫嫉妒）的区别。

example.en: I was angry, but not for the reason you assume.
example.tr: 我很生气，但不是因为你猜想的那个原因。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中澄清复杂动机的有效技巧。

paras.en: “What do you want to do?” I ask. We can hunt, fish, or gather. “Let’s fish at the lake. We can leave our poles and gather in the woods. Get something nice for tonight,” he says. Tonight. After the reaping, everyone is supposed to celebrate. And a lot of people do, out of relief that their children have been spared for another year. But at least two families will pull their shutters, lock their doors, and try to figure out how they will survive the painful weeks to come.
paras.cn: “你想做什么？” 我问。我们可以打猎、钓鱼或采集。“去湖边钓鱼吧。我们可以留下鱼竿，在树林里采集。为今晚准备点好东西，” 他说。今晚。收获日之后，每个人都应该庆祝。很多人也确实这么做了，出于他们的孩子又幸免一年的宽慰。但至少有两个家庭会拉下百叶窗，锁上门，并试图弄清楚他们将如何度过未来痛苦的几周。

vocab.ex: They spent the afternoon gathering wild berries in the forest.
vocab.tr: 他们花了一个下午在森林里采集野莓。

vocab.ex: She sighed out of relief when she heard he was safe.
vocab.tr: 当她听说他安全时，她出于宽慰松了口气。

vocab.ex: The old building was spared from demolition.
vocab.tr: 那座旧楼幸免于被拆除。

vocab.ex: They closed the shutters to keep out the hot sun.
vocab.tr: 他们关上百叶窗以遮挡炎热的太阳。

gram.name: 庆祝与悲伤的并置
gram.pattern: A description of joy followed immediately by a description of sorrow.
gram.function: 作者将大多数家庭的“庆祝”（celebrate）和“宽慰”（relief）与另外两个家庭拉下百叶窗、独自面对痛苦的悲伤并置。这种强烈的对比，深刻地揭示了“收获日”这一事件的双重性：对大多数人是幸免，对少数人则是毁灭。它突出了这个社会制度的残酷性。

example.en: While the city celebrated its victory with fireworks, the soldier mourned his fallen comrades in silence.
example.tr: 当城市用烟花庆祝胜利时，那位士兵在沉默中哀悼他牺牲的战友。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比来揭示事件复杂性和多面性的强大文学技巧。

paras.en: We make out well. The predators ignore us on a day when easier, tastier prey abounds. By late morning, we have a dozen fish, a bag of greens and, best of all, a gallon of strawberries. I found the patch a few years ago, but Gale had the idea to string mesh nets around it to keep out the animals.
paras.cn: 我们收获颇丰。在这一天，捕食者们忽略了我们，因为有更容易、更美味的猎物比比皆是。到上午快结束时，我们有了一打鱼，一袋蔬菜，以及最棒的，一加仑的草莓。几年前我发现了那片草莓地，但盖尔想出了在它周围串起网兜来防止动物进入的主意。

vocab.ex: They really made out well at the flea market, finding several valuable antiques.
vocab.tr: 他们在跳蚤市场上收获颇丰，找到了好几件有价值的古董。

vocab.ex: The lion stalked its prey through the tall grass.
vocab.tr: 狮子在高高的草丛中跟踪它的猎物。

vocab.ex: Opportunities abound for those who are willing to work hard.
vocab.tr: 对于那些愿意努力工作的人来说，机会比比皆是。

vocab.ex: There is a small patch of wildflowers growing in the backyard.
vocab.tr: 后院里长着一小片野花。

vocab.tr: 她帮忙把彩灯挂在圣诞树上。

vocab.ex: He used a fine mesh screen to keep insects out.
vocab.tr: 他用一个细网纱窗来防止昆虫进入。

gram.name: best of all (用于强调)
gram.pattern: ..., and, best of all, ...
gram.function: 用于在一个列表中引出最重要、最令人兴奋的一项，起到强调作用。'...a dozen fish, a bag of greens and, best of all, a gallon of strawberries' 突出了草莓是他们当天最珍贵的收获。

example.en: The hotel had a great pool, a comfortable room, and, best of all, a fantastic view of the ocean.
example.tr: 那家酒店有一个很棒的游泳池，一个舒适的房间，而且最棒的是，还有绝佳的海景。

gram.constraints: 通常用逗号与句子的其余部分隔开。

paras.en: On the way home, we swing by the Hob, the black market that operates in an abandoned warehouse that once held coal. When they came up with a more efficient system that transported the coal directly from the mines to the trains, the Hob gradually took over the space. Most businesses are closed by this time on reaping day, but the black market’s still fairly busy. We easily trade six of the fish for good bread, the other two for salt. Greasy Sae, the bony old woman who sells bowls of hot soup from a large kettle, takes half the greens off our hands in exchange for a couple of chunks of paraffin. We might do a tad better elsewhere, but we make an effort to keep on good terms with Greasy Sae. She’s the only one who can consistently be counted on to buy wild dog. We don’t hunt them on purpose, but if you’re attacked and you take out a dog or two, well, meat is meat. “Once it’s in the soup, I’ll call it beef,” Greasy Sae says with a wink. No one in the Seam would turn up their nose at a good leg of wild dog, but the Peacekeepers who come to the Hob can afford to be a little choosier.
paras.cn: 在回家的路上，我们顺道去了“黑市”（The Hob），那是在一个曾经存放煤炭的废弃仓库里运作的黑市。当他们想出了一个更高效的系统，将煤炭直接从矿井运到火车上后，“黑市”就逐渐占据了这个空间。在收获日的这个时候，大多数生意都关门了，但黑市仍然相当繁忙。我们轻松地用六条鱼换了好面包，另外两条换了盐。油腻的赛伊，那个用一个大水壶卖热汤的骨瘦如柴的老妇人，拿走了我们一半的蔬菜，换了两块石蜡。我们也许在别处能换得更好一点，但我们努力和油腻的赛伊保持良好关系。她是唯一一个能被指望持续购买野狗肉的人。我们不是故意猎杀它们，但如果你被攻击并干掉一两只狗，那么，肉就是肉。“一旦进了汤里，我就会叫它牛肉，” 油腻的赛伊眨着眼说。夹缝地带没人会对一条好的野狗腿嗤之以鼻，但来黑市的维安人员可以稍微挑剔一些。

vocab.tr: 她用石蜡来制作自己的蜡烛。
