vocab.ex: Despite their divorce, they remained on good terms for the sake of their children.
vocab.tr: 尽管离婚了，为了孩子，他们仍然保持着良好的关系。

vocab.ex: He's a reliable friend who can always be counted on in a crisis.
vocab.tr: 他是个可靠的朋友，在危机中总能指望得上。

vocab.ex: He's a picky eater and tends to turn up his nose at vegetables.
vocab.tr: 他是个挑食的人，总对蔬菜嗤之以鼻。

vocab.ex: When it comes to coffee, she's very choosy about the beans.
vocab.tr: 在咖啡方面，她对咖啡豆非常挑剔。

gram.name: 黑色幽默与实用主义
gram.pattern: A morbid statement followed by a practical justification.
gram.function: 通过“肉就是肉”（meat is meat）和“一旦进了汤里，我就会叫它牛肉”（Once it’s in the soup, I’ll call it beef）这些陈述，作者展现了夹缝地带居民在生存压力下的黑色幽默和极端的实用主义。这种语言风格深刻地揭示了在一个食物匮乏的世界里，道德和情感是如何被生存需要所取代的。

example.en: He joked about his own funeral arrangements, saying, 'Well, at least it'll save on heating bills.'
example.tr: 他拿自己的葬礼安排开玩笑说：‘嗯，至少能省点取暖费。’

gram.constraints: 是一种通过幽默来处理严酷或禁忌话题的技巧。

paras.en: When we finish our business at the market, we go to the back door of the mayor’s house to sell half the strawberries, knowing he has a particular fondness for them and can afford our price. The mayor’s daughter, Madge, opens the door. She’s in my year at school. Being the mayor’s daughter, you’d expect her to be a snob, but she’s all right. She just keeps to herself. Like me. Since neither of us really has a group of friends, we seem to end up together a lot at school. Eating lunch, sitting next to each other at assemblies, partnering for sports activities. We rarely talk, which suits us both just fine.
paras.cn: 我们在市场做完生意后，就去市长家的后门卖掉一半的草莓，知道他对草莓有特别的偏爱，而且能付得起我们的价钱。市长的女儿麦琪开了门。她和我在学校同一年级。作为市长的女儿，你会期望她是个势利小人，但她人还不错。她只是独来独往。像我一样。由于我们俩都实在没什么朋友群，我们在学校似乎经常待在一起。吃午饭，在集会上坐在一起，体育活动时搭档。我们很少说话，这正合我们俩的意。

vocab.ex: He has a great fondness for classical music.
vocab.tr: 他非常喜爱古典音乐。

vocab.ex: I can't afford to buy a new car right now.
vocab.tr: 我现在买不起新车。

vocab.ex: He's such a snob; he only talks to people he thinks are important.
vocab.tr: 他真是个势利小人；他只和那些他认为重要的人说话。

vocab.ex: She's a very private person and tends to keep to herself.
vocab.tr: 她是个很注重隐私的人，总喜欢独来独往。

vocab.ex: Despite their differences, they always end up together at family gatherings.
vocab.tr: 尽管他们有分歧，但在家庭聚会上他们最终总会待在一起。

vocab.ex: The principal made an announcement at the morning assembly.
vocab.tr: 校长在早上的集会上宣布了一项通知。

vocab.ex: You can go to the party without me; that suits me just fine.
vocab.tr: 你可以自己去派对，不用管我；那正合我意。

gram.name: 现在分词短语（用于阐述）
gram.pattern: A series of present participle phrases to provide examples.
gram.function: 在陈述了“我们似乎经常待在一起”之后，作者使用了一系列并列的现在分词短语（'Eating lunch, sitting next to each other..., partnering for...'）来具体地阐述和举例说明“待在一起”到底是指哪些情境。这种结构比使用多个完整的句子更简洁、更有节奏感。

example.en: They spent the whole day together, walking in the park, watching a movie, and talking for hours.
example.tr: 他们一整天都在一起，在公园散步，看电影，聊了好几个小时。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中提供具体例子的有效方式。

paras.en: Today her drab school outfit has been replaced by an expensive white dress, and her blonde hair is done up with a pink ribbon. Reaping clothes. “Pretty dress,” says Gale. Madge shoots him a look, trying to see if it’s a genuine compliment or if he’s just being ironic. It is a pretty dress, but she would never be wearing it ordinarily. She presses her lips together and then smiles. “Well, if I end up going to the Capitol, I want to look nice, don’t I?” Now it’s Gale’s turn to be confused. Does she mean it? Or is she messing with him? I’m guessing the second.
paras.cn: 今天，她那单调的校服被一件昂贵的白色连衣裙取代了，她的金发用一根粉色丝带束了起来。是收获日的衣服。“漂亮的裙子，” 盖尔说。麦琪瞥了他一眼，试图看清那是一句真诚的赞美，还是他只是在讽刺。那确实是条漂亮的裙子，但她平时绝不会穿。她抿了抿嘴，然后笑了。“嗯，如果我最终要去国会区，我想看起来漂亮点，不是吗？” 现在轮到盖尔困惑了。她是认真的吗？还是她在耍他？我猜是后者。

vocab.ex: He wore a drab grey suit to the office every day.
vocab.tr: 他每天都穿着单调的灰色西装去办公室。

vocab.ex: The house was all done up for the Christmas party.
vocab.tr: 房子为圣诞派对装饰一新。

vocab.ex: She shot him a warning look when he started to tell the secret.
vocab.tr: 当他开始说那个秘密时，她向他投去一个警告的眼神。

vocab.ex: His apology seemed genuine, so I forgave him.
vocab.tr: 他的道歉看起来很真诚，所以我原谅了他。

vocab.ex: She received a lovely compliment on her new dress.
vocab.tr: 她的新裙子得到了一句美好的赞美。

vocab.ex: It's ironic that the fire station burned down.
vocab.tr: 消防站被烧毁了，这真具有讽刺意味。

vocab.ex: Ordinarily, he is a very calm person.
vocab.tr: 通常，他是一个非常冷静的人。

vocab.ex: I've answered the last two questions; now it's your turn.
vocab.tr: 我回答了最后两个问题；现在轮到你了。

vocab.ex: Are you serious or are you just messing with me?
vocab.tr: 你是认真的还是只是在耍我？

gram.name: 用于分析的内心反问
gram.pattern: A series of questions showing internal analysis of a situation.
gram.function: 在描述了盖尔的困惑之后，叙述者用两个简短的内心反问（'Does she mean it? Or is she messing with him?'）来分析和解读麦琪的意图。这种技巧让读者能进入叙述者的思维过程，和她一起猜测和判断。

example.en: He smiled at me. Was he being friendly? Or did he want something?
example.tr: 他对我笑了。他是在表示友好吗？还是他想要什么？

gram.constraints: 是一种展示角色思考过程的有效叙事技巧。

paras.en: “You won’t be going to the Capitol,” says Gale coolly. His eyes land on a small, circular pin that adorns her dress. Real gold. Beautifully crafted. It could keep a family in bread for months. “What can you have? Five entries? I had six when I was just twelve years old.” “That’s not her fault,” I say. “No, it’s no one’s fault. Just the way it is,” says Gale. Madge’s face has become closed off. She puts the money for the berries in my hand. “Good luck, Katniss.” “You, too,” I say, and the door closes.
paras.cn: “你不会去国会区的，” 盖尔冷冷地说。他的目光落在了她裙子上装饰的一枚圆形小别针上。真金的。制作精美。它能让一个家庭吃上好几个月的面包。“你能有多少个名额？五个？我才十二岁时就有六个了。” “那不是她的错，” 我说。“不，这不是任何人的错。事情就是这样，” 盖尔说。麦琪的脸变得封闭起来。她把买莓果的钱放在我手里。“祝你好运，凯特尼斯。” “你也是，” 我说，门关上了。

vocab.ex: He responded to my question coolly, without any emotion.
vocab.tr: 他冷冷地回答了我的问题，没有任何情绪。

vocab.ex: His eyes landed on the beautiful painting across the room.
vocab.tr: 他的目光落在了房间另一头那幅美丽的画上。

vocab.ex: She wore a small, decorative pin on her jacket.
vocab.tr: 她在夹克上戴了一枚小小的装饰别针。

vocab.ex: Beautiful paintings adorn the walls of the gallery.
vocab.tr: 美丽的画作装饰着画廊的墙壁。

vocab.ex: It was a beautifully crafted wooden box.
vocab.tr: 那是一个制作精美的木盒子。

vocab.ex: He submitted five entries to the contest, hoping to win.
vocab.tr: 他向比赛提交了五个参赛名额，希望能赢。

vocab.ex: After he mentioned her ex-boyfriend, her face became closed off.
vocab.tr: 在他提到她的前男友后，她的表情变得封闭起来。

gram.name: the way it is (用于表达无奈)
gram.pattern: (That's) just the way it is.
gram.function: 用于表达对一种既定的、无法改变的状况的接受和无奈。'Just the way it is' 是盖尔对他所描述的社会不公的一种宿命论式的总结。

example.en: I know it's not fair, but that's just the way it is sometimes.
example.tr: 我知道这不公平，但有时候事情就是这样。

gram.constraints: 是一种非正式的、表达接受现状的说法。

paras.en: We walk toward the Seam in silence. I don’t like that Gale took a dig at Madge, but he’s right, of course. The reaping system is unfair, with the poor getting the worst of it. You become eligible for the reaping the day you turn twelve. That year, your name is entered once. At thirteen, twice. And so on and so on until you reach the age of eighteen, the final year of eligibility, when your name goes into the pool seven times. That’s true for every citizen in all twelve districts in the entire country of Panem.
paras.cn: 我们沉默地走向夹缝地带。我不喜欢盖尔对麦琪的挖苦，但他当然是对的。收获日制度是不公平的，穷人受害最深。你在十二岁生日那天就有资格参加收获日。那一年，你的名字被录入一次。十三岁时，两次。依此类推，直到你十八岁，即资格的最后一年，你的名字会进入抽签池七次。这对帕纳姆国所有十二个区的所有公民都是如此。

vocab.ex: He couldn't resist taking a dig at his rival's new haircut.
vocab.tr: 他忍不住对对手的新发型挖苦了一番。

vocab.ex: In any conflict, it's usually the innocent civilians who get the worst of it.
vocab.tr: 在任何冲突中，通常都是无辜的平民受害最深。

vocab.ex: You must be over 18 to be eligible to vote.
vocab.tr: 你必须年满18岁才有资格投票。

vocab.ex: The shop sells books, pens, notebooks, and so on.
vocab.tr: 这家店卖书、笔、笔记本等等。
match: and so on and so on

vocab.ex: His name was entered into the pool for the grand prize drawing.
vocab.tr: 他的名字被放入了大奖的抽签池中。

gram.name: 通过直接解释进行阐述
gram.pattern: A character explaining the rules or background of their world.
gram.function: 在这一段，叙述者暂停了故事的推进，直接向读者解释了“收获日”制度的运作规则。这种被称为“阐述”（Exposition）的技巧，是向读者提供理解故事世界所必需的背景信息的直接方式。

example.en: The game had one simple rule: the last person standing wins.
example.tr: 游戏有一个简单的规则：最后一个站着的人获胜。

gram.constraints: 好的阐述应该自然地融入叙事，而不是感觉像在上课。

paras.en: But here’s the catch. Say you are poor and starving as we were. You can opt to add your name more times in exchange for tesserae. Each tessera is worth a meager year’s supply of grain and oil for one person. You may do this for each of your family members as well. So, at the age of twelve, I had my name entered four times. Once, because I had to, and three times for tesserae for grain and oil for myself, Prim, and my mother. In fact, every year I have needed to do this. And the entries are cumulative. So now, at the age of sixteen, my name will be in the reaping twenty times. Gale, who is eighteen and has been either helping or single-handedly feeding a family of five for seven years, will have his name in forty-two times.
paras.cn: 但这里有个圈套。假设你像我们一样贫穷和饥饿。你可以选择多次增加你的名字来换取“口粮券”（tesserae）。每张口粮券值一个人一年的微薄谷物和油。你也可以为你的每个家庭成员这样做。所以，在十二岁时，我的名字被录入了四次。一次，因为我必须这么做，还有三次是为了给我自己、波丽姆和我母亲换取谷物和油的口粮券。事实上，每年我都需要这样做。而且录入次数是累积的。所以现在，十六岁的我，我的名字将会在收获日抽签池里出现二十次。盖尔，他十八岁，七年来一直在帮助或独立养活一个五口之家，他的名字将出现四十二次。

vocab.ex: The job offer sounds great, but here's the catch: you have to work on weekends.
vocab.tr: 这份工作听起来很棒，但问题是：你必须在周末工作。

vocab.ex: Instead of taking the bus, she opted to walk.
vocab.tr: 她没有坐公交车，而是选择了步行。

vocab.ex: In the novel, poor families relied on tesserae to survive.
vocab.tr: 在小说中，贫困家庭依靠口粮券生存。

vocab.ex: He survived on a meager salary.
vocab.tr: 他靠微薄的薪水过活。

vocab.ex: The final grade is based on the cumulative score of all exams.
vocab.tr: 最终成绩是基于所有考试的累积分数。

vocab.ex: She single-handedly raised three children while working a full-time job.
vocab.tr: 她一边全职工作，一边独立抚养了三个孩子。

gram.name: 用个人例子进行阐述
gram.pattern: Explaining a rule and then applying it to oneself.
gram.function: 在解释了“口粮券”这个抽象的制度后，叙述者立即用自己和盖尔的具体数字（'my name will be in... twenty times', 'Gale... will have his name in forty-two times'）作为例子。这种从普遍规则到个人实例的转换，使得这个制度的残酷性和不公性对读者来说不再是一个抽象概念，而是一个具体、可感的现实。

example.en: The company policy requires everyone to work overtime. For example, I had to work ten extra hours last week.
example.tr: 公司政策要求每个人都要加班。例如，我上周就不得不额外工作十个小时。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过个人化来增强说服力和情感联系的有效技巧。

paras.en: You can see why someone like Madge, who has never been at risk of needing a tessera, can set him off. The chance of her name being drawn is very slim compared to those of us who live in the Seam. Not impossible, but slim. And even though the rules were set up by the Capitol, not the districts, certainly not Madge’s family, it’s hard not to resent those who don’t have to sign up for tesserae.
paras.cn: 你可以明白为什么像麦琪这样从未有过需要口粮券风险的人，会激怒他。她的名字被抽中的几率，与我们这些生活在夹缝地带的人相比，非常渺茫。不是不可能，但很渺茫。而且尽管规则是由国会区而不是各区制定的，当然也不是麦琪家制定的，但很难不去怨恨那些不必报名领取口粮券的人。

vocab.ex: Smokers are at a higher risk of developing lung cancer.
vocab.tr: 吸烟者患肺癌的风险更高。

vocab.ex: His arrogant comment was enough to set her off.
vocab.tr: 他那傲慢的评论足以激怒她。

vocab.ex: Her ticket was the first to be drawn in the raffle.
vocab.tr: 她的彩票在抽奖中第一个被抽中。

vocab.ex: The chances of winning are very slim, but it's worth a try.
vocab.tr: 获胜的机会非常渺茫，但值得一试。

vocab.ex: She began to resent her boss for the unfair treatment.
vocab.tr: 她开始因不公平的待遇而怨恨她的老板。

gram.name: It's hard not to... (用于表达难以抑制的情感)
gram.pattern: It's hard not to + infinitive
gram.function: 用于表达一种难以避免或抑制的情感或反应。'it’s hard not to resent...' 承认了怨恨这种情绪虽然在理性上可能不公平，但在情感上却是自然的、难以控制的。这个结构深刻地揭示了制度性不公所造成的社会和心理裂痕。

example.en: It's hard not to feel happy for them.
example.tr: 很难不为他们感到高兴。

gram.constraints: 是一种表达情感自然流露的有效方式。

paras.en: Gale knows his anger at Madge is misdirected. On other days, deep in the woods, I’ve listened to him rant about how the tesserae are just another tool to cause misery in our district. A way to plant hatred between the starving workers of the Seam and those who can generally count on supper and thereby ensure we will never trust one another. “It’s to the Capitol’s advantage to have us divided among ourselves,” he might say if there were no ears to hear but mine. If it wasn’t reaping day. If a girl with a gold pin and no tesserae had not made what I’m sure she thought was a harmless comment.
paras.cn: 盖尔知道他对麦琪的愤怒是错误的。在其他日子里，在树林深处，我听过他咆哮，说口粮券只是在我们的区制造痛苦的又一个工具。一种在夹缝地带饥饿的工人和那些通常能指望上晚餐的人之间播下仇恨的方式，从而确保我们永远不会互相信任。“让我们内部分裂对国会区有利，” 如果没有别人只有我听见，他可能会这么说。如果不是收获日。如果一个戴着金别针、没有口粮券的女孩没有说出那句我敢肯定她认为是无害的评论。

vocab.ex: His anger at the waiter was misdirected; it was the kitchen's fault.
vocab.tr: 他对服务员的愤怒是错误的；那是厨房的错。

vocab.ex: He spent an hour ranting about the terrible traffic.
vocab.tr: 他花了一个小时咆哮着抱怨糟糕的交通。

vocab.ex: The war brought nothing but death and misery to the country.
vocab.tr: 战争给这个国家带来的只有死亡和痛苦。

vocab.ex: You can always count on him to be on time.
vocab.tr: 你总可以指望他会准时。

vocab.ex: Please check your work to ensure there are no mistakes.
vocab.tr: 请检查你的工作以确保没有错误。

vocab.ex: His height gives him an advantage in basketball.
vocab.tr: 他的身高让他在篮球方面有优势。

vocab.ex: It was just a harmless joke; don't take it so seriously.
vocab.tr: 那只是个无伤大雅的玩笑，别那么当真。

gram.name: 用于提供背景的层叠条件句
gram.pattern: A statement followed by a series of 'If...' clauses.
gram.function: 在引述了盖尔可能说的话之后，叙述者用了一连串的虚拟条件从句（'if there were no ears...', 'If it wasn’t reaping day.', 'If a girl... had not made...'）来解释为什么他今天没有这么说。这种层叠的条件句结构，深刻地揭示了在压迫性社会中，言论是如何被环境、时间和具体事件所限制的。

example.en: He would have told her the truth. If they had been alone. If he had felt brave enough. If the moment had been right.
example.tr: 他本会告诉她真相的。如果他们当时是单独在一起。如果他当时感觉足够勇敢。如果时机恰当的话。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过列举条件来深化情境复杂性的文学技巧。

paras.en: As we walk, I glance over at Gale’s face, still smoldering underneath his stony expression. His rages seem pointless to me, although I never say so. It’s not that I don’t agree with him. I do. But what good is yelling about the Capitol in the middle of the woods? It doesn’t change anything. It doesn’t make things fair. It doesn’t fill our stomachs. In fact, it scares off the nearby game. I let him yell though. Better he does it in the woods than in the district.
paras.cn: 我们走着，我瞥了一眼盖尔的脸，在他石头般的表情下仍然燃烧着怒火。他的愤怒对我来说似乎毫无意义，虽然我从没这么说过。不是说我不同意他。我同意。但在树林中央对着国会区大喊大叫有什么用呢？那改变不了任何事。那不能让事情变得公平。那填不饱我们的肚子。事实上，那还会吓跑附近的猎物。不过我还是让他喊。他在树林里喊总比在区里喊好。

vocab.ex: She glanced over at the clock to check the time.
vocab.tr: 她瞥了一眼时钟看时间。

vocab.ex: Anger was still smoldering in his eyes long after the argument.
vocab.tr: 争吵过后很久，他的眼中仍然燃烧着怒火。

vocab.ex: He gave me a stony stare and didn't say a word.
vocab.tr: 他冷冷地瞪着我，一言不发。

vocab.ex: It's pointless to argue with him; he'll never change his mind.
vocab.tr: 和他争论毫无意义；他永远不会改变主意。

vocab.ex: What good is having a car if you never drive it?
vocab.tr: 有辆车却从不开，那有什么用？

gram.name: 用于表达实用主义的平行否定
gram.pattern: It doesn't [action A]. It doesn't [action B]. It doesn't [action C].
gram.function: 通过一连串平行的否定句来反驳盖尔的愤怒，叙述者清晰地阐述了她的实用主义观点。她用具体的、与生存直接相关的标准（'change anything', 'make things fair', 'fill our stomachs'）来衡量愤怒的价值，并得出结论——它是无用的。这个结构深刻地揭示了她与盖尔在性格和应对策略上的根本区别。

example.en: Worrying doesn't solve the problem. It doesn't help you feel better. It doesn't change the past.
example.tr: 担忧解决不了问题。它不会让你感觉更好。它也改变不了过去。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过列举否定来加强论点的修辞手法。

paras.en: Gale and I divide our spoils, leaving two fish, a couple of loaves of good bread, greens, a quart of strawberries, salt, paraffin, and a bit of money for each. “See you in the square,” I say. “Wear something pretty,” he says flatly.
paras.cn: 盖尔和我分了我们的战利品，每人留下两条鱼，几条好面包，蔬菜，一夸脱草莓，盐，石蜡，还有一点钱。“广场上见，” 我说。“穿件漂亮的衣服，” 他平淡地说。

vocab.ex: They decided to divide the profits equally between them.
vocab.tr: 他们决定将利润在他们之间平分。

vocab.ex: The victorious army returned to the city with their spoils.
vocab.tr: 胜利的军队带着他们的战利品回到了城市。

vocab.ex: She bought a quart of milk at the store.
vocab.tr: 她在商店买了一夸脱牛奶。

vocab.ex: He flatly refused to help us.
vocab.tr: 他断然拒绝帮助我们。

gram.name: 连接词省略（用于列举物品）
gram.pattern: A list of nouns or noun phrases without the final 'and'.
gram.function: 在列举他们分配的物品时，作者使用了一长串用逗号分隔的名词短语，省略了最后的 'and'。这种连接词省略的手法，创造了一种快速、务实的节奏，模仿了清点物品的清单式思维，突出了他们交易的日常性和熟练性。

example.en: I need to pack a toothbrush, toothpaste, soap, a towel.
example.tr: 我需要打包牙刷、牙膏、肥皂、一条毛巾。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过省略来增强节奏感的修辞技巧。

paras.en: At home, I find my mother and sister are ready to go. My mother wears a fine dress from her apothecary days. Prim is in my first reaping outfit, a skirt and ruffled blouse. It’s a bit big on her, but my mother has made it stay with pins. Even so, she’s having trouble keeping the blouse tucked in at the back.
paras.cn: 在家里，我发现我母亲和妹妹已经准备好要走了。我母亲穿着一件她药店时期留下的好裙子。波丽姆穿着我第一次参加收获日时的套装，一条裙子和一件荷叶边衬衫。对她来说有点大，但我母亲用别针把它固定好了。即便如此，她还是很难把衬衫的后摆塞好。

vocab.ex: Are you packed and ready to go?
vocab.tr: 你打包好，准备出发了吗？

vocab.ex: She wore a stylish new outfit to the party.
vocab.tr: 她穿着一套时髦的新套装去参加派对。

vocab.ex: She wore a white blouse with a ruffled collar.
vocab.tr: 她穿着一件带有荷叶边领子的白衬衫。

vocab.ex: He used tape to make the poster stay on the wall.
vocab.tr: 他用胶带把海报固定在墙上。

vocab.ex: For a formal look, your shirt should be tucked in.
vocab.tr: 为了看起来正式，你的衬衫应该塞进去。

gram.name: 使役动词 (make sth do sth)
gram.pattern: make + object + infinitive
gram.function: 表示“使/让某物做某事”。'...my mother has made it stay with pins' 意思是“我母亲用别针让它固定住了”，强调了母亲为了让衣服合身而采取的行动。

example.en: The strong wind made the door slam shut.
example.tr: 强风让门砰地一声关上了。

gram.constraints: 在主动语态中，make, let, have 后面跟不带 to 的不定式作宾补。

paras.en: A tub of warm water waits for me. I scrub off the dirt and sweat from the woods and even wash my hair. To my surprise, my mother has laid out one of her own lovely dresses for me. A soft blue thing with matching shoes. “Are you sure?” I ask. I’m trying to get past rejecting offers of help from her. For a while, I was so angry, I wouldn’t allow her to do anything for me. And this is something special. Her clothes from her past are very precious to her.
paras.cn: 一盆温水等着我。我擦去树林里的泥土和汗水，甚至洗了我的头发。令我惊讶的是，我母亲为我拿出了一件她自己的漂亮裙子。一件柔和的蓝色东西，配有相配的鞋子。“你确定吗？” 我问。我正在努力克服拒绝她帮助的习惯。有一段时间，我非常生气，不让她为我做任何事。而这是一件特别的东西。她过去留下的衣服对她来说非常珍贵。

vocab.ex: She filled the tub with warm water for a relaxing bath.
vocab.tr: 她往浴缸里放满温水，准备泡个舒服的澡。

vocab.ex: It took a long time to scrub off the dried paint.
vocab.tr: 花了很长时间才把干掉的油漆擦掉。

vocab.ex: To my surprise, he had already finished all the work.
vocab.tr: 令我惊讶的是，他已经完成了所有的工作。

vocab.ex: She laid out her clothes for the next day before going to bed.
vocab.tr: 她睡前把第二天的衣服摆了出来。

vocab.ex: It was hard for her to get past the death of her pet.
vocab.tr: 她很难从宠物的死亡中走出来。

vocab.ex: This old watch is very precious to me; it was my grandfather's.
vocab.tr: 这块旧手表对我来说非常珍贵；它是我祖父的。

gram.name: 内心冲突与和解
gram.pattern: A statement of effort to change a past negative behavior.
gram.function: 句子 'I’m trying to get past rejecting offers of help from her.' 深刻地揭示了主角的内心世界。它不仅承认了自己过去的行为（拒绝帮助），还表明了她正在有意识地努力改变。这个自我剖析的时刻，标志着她与母亲关系中一个重要的、走向和解的转折点。

example.en: I'm trying to be more patient with my little brother.
example.tr: 我正在努力对我的小弟弟更有耐心。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过内心独白来展示角色成长的有效技巧。

paras.en: “Of course. Let’s put your hair up, too,” she says. I let her towel-dry it and braid it up on my head. I can hardly recognize myself in the cracked mirror that leans against the wall. “You look beautiful,” says Prim in a hushed voice. “And nothing like myself,” I say. I hug her, because I know these next few hours will be terrible for her. Her first reaping. She’s about as safe as you can get, since she’s only entered once. I wouldn’t let her take out any tesserae. But she’s worried about me. That the unthinkable might happen.
paras.cn: “当然。我们把你的头发也盘起来吧，” 她说。我让她用毛巾擦干我的头发，然后把它在头上编成辫子。我几乎认不出斜靠在墙上的裂纹镜子里的自己了。“你看起来真美，” 波丽姆用压低的声音说。“而且一点也不像我自己，” 我说。我拥抱她，因为我知道接下来的几个小时对她来说将是可怕的。她的第一次收获日。她几乎是你能达到的最安全的状态了，因为她的名字只被录入了一次。我不会让她去领取任何口粮券。但她担心我。担心那不可想象的事情可能会发生。

vocab.ex: After his shower, he quickly towel-dried his hair.
vocab.tr: 淋浴后，他迅速用毛巾擦干了头发。

vocab.ex: She decided to braid up her long hair to keep it out of her face.
vocab.tr: 她决定把长发编起来，以免挡住脸。

vocab.ex: The old teacup was cracked but still usable.
vocab.tr: 那个旧茶杯有裂纹，但还能用。

vocab.ex: They spoke in hushed voices in the library.
vocab.tr: 他们在图书馆里压低声音说话。

vocab.word: as safe as you can get
vocab.ex: With all these security measures, this building is as safe as you can get.
vocab.tr: 有了所有这些安保措施，这栋楼是极其安全的。
match: as safe as you can get

vocab.ex: In those days, a woman becoming president was almost unthinkable.
vocab.tr: 在那些日子里，一个女人成为总统几乎是不可想象的。

gram.name: 同位语（用于澄清）
gram.pattern: Noun Phrase. + Noun Phrase.
gram.function: 使用一个独立的名词短语（'Her first reaping.'）作为同位语，来解释和强调前一句话 'these next few hours will be terrible for her' 的具体原因。这种结构比使用 'because it is her first reaping' 更简洁、更有力，也更具文学性。

example.en: He faced his greatest challenge. The final exam.
example.tr: 他面临着他最大的挑战。期末考试。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中增加节奏感和强调的技巧。

paras.en: I protect Prim in every way I can, but I’m powerless against the reaping. The anguish I always feel when she’s in pain wells up in my chest and threatens to register on my (ace. I notice her blouse has pulled out of her skirt in the back again and force myself to stay calm. “Tuck your tail in, little duck,” I say, smoothing the blouse back in place. Prim giggles and gives me a small “Quack.” “Quack yourself,” I say with a light laugh. The kind only Prim can draw out of me. “Come on, let’s eat,” I say and plant a quick kiss on the top of her head.
paras.cn: 我尽我所能地在各方面保护波丽姆，但我对收获日无能为力。每当她痛苦时我总会感到的那种剧痛在我胸中涌起，并威胁要显现在我的脸上。我注意到她的衬衫后摆又从裙子里抽出来了，我强迫自己保持冷静。“把你的尾巴塞进去，小鸭子，” 我说，一边把衬衫抚平归位。波丽姆咯咯地笑了，给了我一声小小的“嘎”。“你自己才嘎呢，” 我轻笑着说。那种只有波丽姆才能引我发出的笑。“来吧，我们吃饭吧，” 我说，并在她的头顶上飞快地亲了一下。

vocab.ex: He felt powerless against the forces of nature.
vocab.tr: 他感觉自己在大自然的力量面前无能为力。

vocab.ex: She was in anguish over her son's illness.
vocab.tr: 她因儿子的病而痛苦不堪。

vocab.ex: Tears started to well up in her eyes.
vocab.tr: 泪水开始在她眼中涌动。

vocab.ex: Surprise registered on his face when he saw the gift.
vocab.tr: 当他看到礼物时，惊讶之情显现在他的脸上。

vocab.ex: She used her hands to smooth her dress back in place after sitting down.
vocab.tr: 坐下后，她用手把裙子抚平归位。
match: smoothing the blouse back in place

vocab.ex: The two girls started to giggle during the quiet movie.
vocab.tr: 在安静的电影放映期间，那两个女孩开始咯咯地笑。

vocab.ex: A good teacher can draw out the best in every student.
vocab.tr: 一位好老师能引导出每个学生最好的一面。

vocab.ex: He bent down and planted a kiss on his daughter's forehead.
vocab.tr: 他弯下腰，在他女儿的额头上亲了一下。

gram.name: 将情绪转化为行动
gram.pattern: A character feeling a strong negative emotion forces themselves to perform a calm, caring action.
gram.function: 主角内心充满了强烈的“痛苦”（anguish），但她没有任其爆发，而是“强迫自己保持冷静”（force myself to stay calm），并将这种情绪能量转化为一个具体的、充满关爱的保护性动作——为妹妹整理衣服。这种从内心情感到外在行动的转化，深刻地展示了她的责任感和对妹妹的爱。

example.en: Though he was furious, he forced himself to speak in a calm voice.
example.tr: 尽管他怒不可遏，他还是强迫自己用平静的声音说话。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过行为来揭示人物内在力量和价值观的写作技巧。

paras.en: The fish and greens are already cooking in a stew, but that will be for supper. We decide to save the strawberries and bakery bread for this evening’s meal, to make it special we say. Instead we drink milk from Prim’s goat, Lady, and eat the rough bread made from the tessera grain, although no one has much appetite anyway.
paras.cn: 鱼和蔬菜已经在炖菜里煮着了，但那是晚餐吃的。我们决定把草莓和面包店的面包留到今晚这餐，我们说是为了让它变得特别。相反，我们喝了波丽姆的山羊“女士”的奶，吃了用口粮券谷物做的粗面包，尽管反正也没人有什么胃口。

vocab.ex: On a cold day, there's nothing better than a warm bowl of beef stew.
vocab.tr: 在寒冷的日子里，没什么比一碗热腾腾的炖牛肉更好的了。

vocab.ex: What are we having for supper tonight?
vocab.tr: 我们今晚晚餐吃什么？

vocab.ex: The small farm had a few chickens and a goat.
vocab.tr: 那个小农场有几只鸡和一只山羊。

vocab.ex: Each tessera provided a small amount of grain for a year.
vocab.tr: 每张口粮券能提供一年份的少量谷物。

vocab.ex: He had a huge appetite and ate three plates of food.
vocab.tr: 他胃口很好，吃了三盘食物。

gram.name: 对比餐食的象征意义
gram.pattern: Contrasting a simple meal with a planned special meal.
gram.function: 通过将他们现在吃的“粗面包”（rough bread）与计划留到晚上的“特别”餐食（草莓和面包店面包）进行对比，作者用食物作为象征。现在的食物代表了他们日常的、严酷的现实；而推迟享用的美食，则象征着一种对未来的、不确定的希望——希望晚上还有心情和机会去“庆祝”。

example.en: They ate dry bread for lunch, saving the small piece of cheese for a special dinner.
example.tr: 他们午餐吃干面包，把那一小块奶酪留作特别的晚餐。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过具体物品来象征抽象观念和情感的文学技巧。

paras.en: At one o’clock, we head for the square. Attendance is mandatory unless you are on death’s door. This evening, officials will come around and check to see if this is the case. If not, you’ll be imprisoned. It’s too bad, really, that they hold the reaping in the square — one of the few places in District 12 that can be pleasant. The square’s surrounded by shops, and on public market days, especially if there’s good weather, it has a holiday feel to it. But today, despite the bright banners hanging on the buildings, there’s an air of grimness. The camera crews, perched like buzzards on rooftops, only add to the effect.
paras.cn: 一点钟，我们前往广场。出席是强制性的，除非你快死了。今天晚上，官员们会过来检查情况是否属实。如果不是，你就会被监禁。真的很可惜，他们偏偏在广场上举行收获日——第12区少数几个能令人愉快的地方之一。广场周围都是商店，在公共集市日，尤其如果天气好，这里有一种节日的感觉。但今天，尽管建筑物上挂着鲜艳的横幅，却有一种严峻的气氛。摄影队，像秃鹰一样栖在屋顶上，更增添了这种效果。

vocab.ex: After breakfast, we decided to head for the mountains.
vocab.tr: 早餐后，我们决定前往山区。

vocab.ex: Attendance at the meeting is mandatory for all employees.
vocab.tr: 所有员工都必须强制出席这次会议。

vocab.ex: After the accident, he was on death's door for several days.
vocab.tr: 事故发生后，他有好几天都处于濒死状态。

vocab.ex: He was imprisoned for ten years for his crimes.
vocab.tr: 他因罪行被监禁了十年。

vocab.ex: Despite the sunny weather, there was an air of grimness at the funeral.
vocab.tr: 尽管阳光明媚，葬礼上却弥漫着一种严峻的气氛。

vocab.ex: A large buzzard circled high in the sky.
vocab.tr: 一只巨大的秃鹰在高空中盘旋。

gram.name: 作为负面象征的明喻
gram.pattern: Comparing a group to a predatory animal.
gram.function: 将“摄影队”（camera crews）比作“栖息的秃鹰”（perched like buzzards），这个明喻不仅仅是一个视觉上的描述。秃鹰是食腐动物，它们的出现通常与死亡和不幸联系在一起。因此，这个比喻深刻地揭示了国会区的媒体本质：它们不是中立的观察者，而是以他人的痛苦和死亡为食的捕食者。

example.en: The paparazzi surrounded the celebrity like a pack of wolves.
example.tr: 狗仔队像一群狼一样包围了那位名人。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过比喻来揭示事物本质的强大文学技巧。

paras.en: People file in silently and sign in. The reaping is a good opportunity for the Capitol to keep tabs on the population as well. Twelve-through eighteen-year-olds are herded into roped areas marked off by ages, the oldest in the front, the young ones, like Prim, toward the back. Family members line up around the perimeter, holding tightly to one another’s hands. But there are others, too, who have no one they love at stake, or who no longer care, who slip among the crowd, taking bets on the two kids whose names will be drawn. Odds are given on their ages, whether they’re Seam or merchant, if they will break down and weep. Most refuse dealing with the racketeers but carefully, carefully. These same people tend to be informers, and who hasn’t broken the law? I could be shot on a daily basis for hunting, but the appetites of those in charge protect me. Not everyone can claim the same.
paras.cn: 人们静静地排队进入并签到。收获日也是国会区监视人口的好机会。十二岁到十八岁的人被赶进按年龄划分的绳索区域，年纪最大的在前面，像波丽姆这样的小孩子在后面。家人则在周边排成一排，紧紧地握着彼此的手。但也有其他人，他们没有心爱的人在其中冒险，或者已经不再在乎，他们混在人群中，对将要被抽中的两个孩子的名字下注。赔率根据他们的年龄、他们是来自夹缝地带还是商人阶层、他们是否会崩溃哭泣而定。大多数人拒绝和这些敲诈者打交道，但都非常非常小心。这些人往往也是告密者，而谁又没犯过法呢？我每天都可能因为打猎而被枪毙，但当权者的胃口保护了我。不是每个人都能声称拥有同样的待遇。

vocab.ex: The students began to file in to the auditorium for the assembly.
vocab.tr: 学生们开始排队进入礼堂参加集会。

vocab.ex: The detective was hired to keep tabs on the suspect.
vocab.tr: 侦探被雇来监视嫌疑人。

vocab.ex: The teacher herded the noisy children onto the bus.
vocab.tr: 老师把吵闹的孩子们赶上了巴士。

vocab.ex: The guards patrolled the perimeter of the military base.
vocab.tr: 警卫在军事基地的周边巡逻。

vocab.ex: With thousands of dollars at stake, the final round of the game show was very tense.
vocab.tr: 由于有数千美元的奖金悬而未决，游戏节目的最后一轮非常紧张。

vocab.ex: People were taking bets on which horse would win the race.
vocab.tr: 人们在就哪匹马会赢得比赛下注。

vocab.ex: She broke down and cried when she heard the bad news.
vocab.tr: 当她听到那个坏消息时，她崩溃大哭。

vocab.ex: The shop owner was forced to pay money to the local racketeers.
vocab.tr: 店主被迫向当地的敲诈者付钱。

vocab.ex: The police got a tip from an anonymous informer.
vocab.tr: 警方从一个匿名告密者那里得到了线报。

vocab.ex: He exercises on a daily basis to stay healthy.
vocab.tr: 他每天都锻炼以保持健康。

vocab.ex: If you have a complaint, you should speak to those in charge.
vocab.tr: 如果你有投诉，你应该和当权者谈谈。

gram.name: 非人化语言 (herd)
gram.pattern: Using animal-related verbs for humans.
gram.function: 通过使用通常用于描述牲畜的动词 'herd'（驱赶）来描述孩子们被赶入指定区域，作者在语言上进行了非人化处理。这个词的选择，深刻地揭示了国会区是如何看待各区人民的——不是作为个体，而是像牲畜一样可以被随意操控和献祭的群体。

example.en: The prisoners were penned in a small yard.
example.tr: 囚犯们被关在一个小院子里。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过词汇选择来揭示权力关系和态度的强大技巧。

paras.en: Anyway, Gale and I agree that if we have to choose between dying of hunger and a bullet in the head, the bullet would be much quicker. The space gets tighter, more claustrophobic as people arrive. The square’s quite large, but not enough to hold District 12’s population of about eight thousand. Latecomers are directed to the adjacent streets, where they can watch the event on screens as it’s televised live by the state.
paras.cn: 总之，盖尔和我都同意，如果必须在饿死和一枪爆头之间选择，子弹会快得多。随着人们的到来，空间变得越来越紧，越来越幽闭恐怖。广场很大，但不足以容纳第12区大约八千的人口。迟到的人被引导到邻近的街道，他们可以在那里的屏幕上观看国家直播的活动。

vocab.ex: He said he'd rather face a bullet in the head than betray his country.
vocab.tr: 他说他宁愿面对一枪爆头，也不愿背叛他的国家。

vocab.ex: The small, crowded elevator felt very claustrophobic.
vocab.tr: 那个又小又挤的电梯让人感觉非常幽闭恐怖。

vocab.ex: The latecomers had to stand at the back of the room.
vocab.tr: 迟到的人不得不站在房间后面。

vocab.ex: Our house is adjacent to a large park.
vocab.tr: 我们的房子紧挨着一个大公园。

vocab.ex: The championship game will be televised live to millions of viewers.
vocab.tr: 冠军赛将向数百万观众进行电视直播。

gram.name: 用于增加紧张感的比较级
gram.pattern: Adjective-er, more + Adjective
gram.function: 通过使用两个并列的比较级形容词 'tighter, more claustrophobic'，作者描绘了一个随着人群涌入而逐渐恶化的环境。这种递进的描述，不仅是物理空间的感受，也反映了主角内心不断加剧的紧张和压迫感。

example.en: As the storm approached, the sky grew darker, more threatening.
example.tr: 随着暴风雨的临近，天空变得更黑，更具威胁性。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过环境描写来反映内心状态的技巧。

paras.en: I find myself standing in a clump of sixteens from the Seam. We all exchange terse nods then focus our attention on the temporary stage that is set up before the Justice Building. It holds three chairs, a podium, and two large glass balls, one for the boys and one for the girls. I stare at the paper slips in the girls’ ball. Twenty of them have Katniss Everdeen written on them in careful handwriting.
paras.cn: 我发现自己站在一堆来自夹缝地带的十六岁少年中。我们都简短地交换了点头示意，然后将注意力集中在司法大楼前搭建的临时舞台上。上面有三把椅子，一个讲台，还有两个大玻璃球，一个给男孩，一个给女孩。我盯着女孩那个球里的纸条。其中有二十张用仔细的笔迹写着凯特尼斯·伊夫狄恩。

vocab.ex: A clump of wildflowers was growing by the side of the road.
vocab.tr: 路边长着一丛野花。

vocab.mean: 简短的（有时带有不友好之意）
vocab.ex: He gave a terse nod of acknowledgement and walked away.
vocab.tr: 他简短地点头示意，然后走开了。

vocab.ex: They built a temporary shelter after the storm.
vocab.tr: 暴风雨过后，他们搭建了一个临时避难所。

vocab.ex: The winner stepped up to the podium to receive her medal.
vocab.tr: 获胜者走上领奖台接受她的奖牌。

vocab.ex: She wrote her phone number on a slip of paper.
vocab.tr: 她把她的电话号码写在一张小纸条上。

gram.name: 聚焦于特定细节以营造悬念
gram.pattern: Shifting from a general view to a single, personal detail.
gram.function: 叙述的焦点从对整个舞台的宏观描述，突然缩小到对玻璃球里写有自己名字的纸条的特写。这种从“公共”到“个人”的急剧转换，以及具体数字“二十张”的揭示，极大地增强了悬念和主角所面临的个人危险感。

example.en: The entire army stood ready for battle. But his eyes were fixed on a single enemy soldier across the field.
example.tr: 整支军队都已准备好战斗。但他的眼睛却锁定在战场对面一个单独的敌兵身上。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过改变叙事尺度来控制读者注意力和情感的有效技巧。

paras.en: Two of the three chairs fill with Madge’s father, Mayor Undersee, who’s a tall, balding man, and Effie Trinket, District 12’s escort, fresh from the Capitol with her scary white grin, pinkish hair, and spring green suit. They murmur to each other and then look with concern at the empty seat. Just as the town clock strikes two, the mayor steps up to the podium and begins to read. It’s the same story every year. He tells of the history of Panem, the country that rose up out of the ashes of a place that was once called North America. He lists the disasters, the droughts, the storms, the fires, the encroaching seas that swallowed up so much of the land, the brutal war for what little sustenance remained. The result was Panem, a shining Capitol ringed by thirteen districts, which brought peace and prosperity to its citizens. Then came the Dark Days, the uprising of the districts against the Capitol. Twelve were defeated, the thirteenth obliterated. The Treaty of Treason gave us the new laws to guarantee peace and, as our yearly reminder that the Dark Days must never be repeated, it gave us the Hunger Games.
paras.cn: 三把椅子中的两把被麦琪的父亲，安德西市长，一个高个、秃顶的男人，和来自国会区的艾菲·特林켓填满了。她是第12区的领队，带着她可怕的白色笑容、粉红色的头发和春绿色的套装。他们互相低语，然后担忧地看着那把空椅子。就在镇上的钟敲响两点时，市长走上讲台开始宣读。每年都是同样的故事。他讲述了帕纳姆的历史，这个国家是从一个曾经叫做北美的地方的灰烬中崛起的。他列举了各种灾难，干旱、风暴、火灾、不断侵蚀的海洋吞噬了如此多的土地，以及为剩下那点微薄食物而进行的残酷战争。结果就是帕纳姆，一个由十三个区环绕的闪亮国会区，为它的公民带来了和平与繁荣。然后是黑暗岁月，各区对国会区的起义。十二个区被击败，第十三个区被彻底摧毁。《叛国条约》给了我们保证和平的新法律，并且，作为每年提醒我们黑暗岁月绝不能重演的警示，它给了我们饥饿游戏。

vocab.ex: He was a middle-aged man, tall and balding.
vocab.tr: 他是一个中年男人，高个，开始秃顶。

vocab.ex: Each tribute was assigned an escort from the Capitol.
vocab.tr: 每个贡品都被指派了一名来自国会区的领队。

vocab.ex: He had a mischievous grin on his face.
vocab.tr: 他脸上挂着一丝顽皮的笑容。

vocab.ex: The long drought caused a severe water shortage.
vocab.tr: 长期的干旱导致了严重的水资源短缺。

vocab.ex: They fought to protect their land from the encroaching desert.
vocab.tr: 他们奋力保护自己的土地，抵御不断侵蚀的沙漠。

vocab.ex: The small farm provided all the sustenance the family needed.
vocab.tr: 那个小农场提供了这个家庭所需的所有食物。

vocab.ex: The government quickly crushed the rebellion's uprising.
vocab.tr: 政府迅速镇压了叛乱的起义。

vocab.ex: The bombing raid threatened to obliterate the entire city.
vocab.tr: 那次轰炸袭击威胁要将整个城市夷为平地。

vocab.ex: He was executed for treason against the king.
vocab.tr: 他因叛国罪被处决。

gram.name: 世界历史背景阐述
gram.pattern: A formal speech detailing the history and rules of a society.
gram.function: 这一大段是纯粹的背景阐述（Exposition），通过市长的年度演讲，向读者和故事中的听众系统地介绍了帕纳姆国的历史、“黑暗岁月”的起因，以及“饥饿游戏”作为一种惩罚和警示的由来。这种仪式化的叙述，突显了国会区对历史的官方、单方面的解释权。

example.en: The opening scene of the film was a narrator explaining the long war that had led to the current state of the world.
example.tr: 电影的开场是一个旁白，解释了导致世界现状的那场漫长的战争。

gram.constraints: 是科幻和奇幻小说中建立世界观的常用手法。

paras.en: The rules of the Hunger Games are simple. In punishment for the uprising, each of the twelve districts must provide one girl and one boy, called tributes, to participate. The twenty-four tributes will be imprisoned in a vast outdoor arena that could hold anything from a burning desert to a frozen wasteland. Over a period of several weeks, the competitors must fight to the death. The last tribute standing wins.
paras.cn: 饥饿游戏的规则很简单。作为对起义的惩罚，十二个区中的每一个都必须提供一个女孩和一个男孩，被称为“贡品”，来参加。二十四名贡品将被囚禁在一个巨大的户外竞技场中，那里可能包含从燃烧的沙漠到冰封的荒原的任何东西。在几周的时间里，参赛者必须战斗至死。最后站着的那个贡品获胜。

vocab.ex: As a punishment for being late, he had to stay after school.
vocab.tr: 作为迟到的惩罚，他放学后必须留下来。

vocab.ex: The concert was a tribute to the legendary musician.
vocab.tr: 那场音乐会是对那位传奇音乐家的致敬。

vocab.ex: Everyone is encouraged to participate in the discussion.
vocab.tr: 鼓励每个人都参与讨论。

vocab.ex: The gladiators fought to the death in the ancient arena.
vocab.tr: 角斗士们在古老的竞技场中战斗至死。

vocab.ex: The nuclear bomb turned the once-thriving city into a desolate wasteland.
vocab.tr: 核弹将这座曾经繁荣的城市变成了一片荒凉的废土。

vocab.ex: There are over one hundred competitors in this year's marathon.
vocab.tr: 今年的马拉松比赛有一百多名参赛者。

vocab.ex: The two warriors swore to fight to the death.
vocab.tr: 那两名战士发誓要战斗至死。

gram.name: 同位语 (called...)
gram.pattern: Noun, + called + Name.

components.role: 过去分词短语作同位语

gram.function: 用于对前面的名词（'one girl and one boy'）提供一个特定的称谓。'called tributes' 澄清了这些被选中的男孩女孩在游戏中的官方名称。

example.en: He lives in a small town called Sunnyvale.
example.tr: 他住在一个叫做森尼维尔的小镇。

gram.constraints: 是一种常见的提供名称或称谓的方式。

paras.en: Taking the kids from our districts, forcing them to kill one another while we watch — this is the Capitol’s way of reminding us how totally we are at their mercy. How little chance we would stand of surviving another rebellion. Whatever words they use, the real message is clear. “Look how we take your children and sacrifice them and there’s nothing you can do. If you lift a finger, we will destroy every last one of you. Just as we did in District Thirteen.”
paras.cn: 从我们的区带走孩子，强迫他们在我们观看时自相残杀——这是国会区提醒我们，我们是如何完全任其摆布的方式。我们再次叛乱的生还机会是多么渺茫。无论他们使用什么言辞，真正的信息是清晰的。“看我们如何带走你们的孩子并献祭他们，而你们无能为力。如果你们敢动一根手指，我们会将你们每一个人都彻底摧毁。就像我们对第十三区做的那样。”

vocab.ex: The small boat was at the mercy of the violent storm.
vocab.tr: 那艘小船在狂暴的风暴中任其摆布。

vocab.ex: Against such a strong opponent, he didn't stand a chance of winning.
vocab.tr: 面对如此强大的对手，他没有获胜的机会。

vocab.ex: The king's cruel policies led to a rebellion among the people.
vocab.tr: 国王的残酷政策导致了人民的叛乱。

vocab.ex: In the ancient ritual, they would sacrifice an animal to the gods.
vocab.tr: 在古代仪式中，他们会向神献祭一只动物。

vocab.mean: 动一根手指（通常用于否定句，表示不帮忙或不反抗）
vocab.ex: He wouldn't lift a finger to help his own brother.
vocab.tr: 他连一根手指头都懒得动去帮助自己的兄弟。

vocab.ex: He ate every last one of the cookies.
vocab.tr: 他把饼干吃得一个不剩。

gram.name: 动名词短语作主语
gram.pattern: VERB-ing... and VERB-ing...
gram.function: 使用并列的动名词短语（'Taking the kids...' 和 'forcing them to kill...'）作为句子的主语，将国会区的残酷行为概括为两个核心动作，并引出其背后的真实目的。这种结构在语法上是简洁的，在情感上是强有力的。

example.en: Working hard and staying focused is the key to success.
example.tr: 努力工作和保持专注是成功的关键。

gram.constraints: 动名词短语作主语时，谓语动词通常用单数形式。

paras.en: To make it humiliating as well as torturous, the Capitol requires us to treat the Hunger Games as a festivity, a sporting event pitting every district against the others. The last tribute alive receives a life of ease back home, and their district will be showered with prizes, largely consisting of food. All year, the Capitol will show the winning district gifts of grain and oil and even delicacies like sugar while the rest of us battle starvation.
paras.cn: 为了让它既折磨人又具侮辱性，国会区要求我们将饥饿游戏当作一场庆典，一场让每个区与其他区对抗的体育赛事。最后活着的那个贡品在家乡会获得安逸的生活，而他们所在的区将被 showered with 奖品，主要包括食物。一整年，国会区都会向获胜的区展示谷物、油甚至像糖这样的美食，而我们其余的人则在与饥饿作斗争。

vocab.ex: It was a humiliating defeat for the once-champion team.
vocab.tr: 对那支曾经的冠军队伍来说，这是一场侮辱性的失败。

vocab.ex: The long interrogation was a torturous experience.
vocab.tr: 那场漫长的审讯是一次折磨人的经历。

vocab.ex: The city was full of light and festivity during the holiday season.
vocab.tr: 节日期间，城市里充满了灯光和庆典气氛。

vocab.ex: The competition pitted the two best players against each other.
vocab.tr: 比赛让两位最优秀的选手互相对抗。

vocab.ex: After retiring, he looked forward to a life of ease.
vocab.tr: 退休后，他期盼着一种安逸的生活。

vocab.ex: After her performance, the singer was showered with flowers and applause.
vocab.tr: 表演结束后，那位歌手收到了如雨点般的花朵和掌声。

vocab.ex: Caviar is considered a great delicacy in many parts of the world.
vocab.tr: 鱼子酱在世界许多地方被认为是珍馐美味。

vocab.ex: During the famine, the villagers had to battle starvation every day.
vocab.tr: 饥荒期间，村民们每天都必须与饥饿作斗争。

gram.name: 使用 'while' 表示对比
gram.pattern: Clause A + while + Clause B
gram.function: 用于引出一个与主句内容形成鲜明对比的从句。'...the Capitol will show the winning district gifts... while the rest of us battle starvation' 这一句，通过将一个区的富足与其余区的饥饿并置，深刻地揭示了饥饿游戏作为一种政治控制工具的残酷本质——它不仅是惩罚，更是通过制造不平等来分化各区。

example.en: She spent the evening relaxing at home, while he was still working hard at the office.
example.tr: 她在家轻松地度过了晚上，而他仍在办公室辛苦工作。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中强调对比和不平等的有效方式。

paras.en: “It is both a time for repentance and a time for thanks,” intones the mayor. Then he reads the list of past District 12 victors. In seventy-four years, we have had exactly two. Only one is still alive. Haymitch Abernathy, a paunchy, middle-aged man, who at this moment appears hollering something unintelligible, staggers onto the stage, and falls into the third chair. He’s drunk. Very. The crowd responds with its token applause, but he’s confused and tries to give Effie Trinket a big hug, which she barely manages to fend off.
paras.cn: “这既是一个悔罪的时刻，也是一个感恩的时刻，” 市长吟诵道。然后他宣读了第12区过去的获胜者名单。七十四年来，我们只有两个。只有一个还活着。海米契·阿伯纳西，一个大腹便便的中年男人，此刻他大喊着一些听不懂的话出现，摇摇晃晃地走上舞台，倒在第三把椅子上。他喝醉了。非常醉。人群报以象征性的掌声，但他很困惑，试图给艾菲·特林켓一个大大的拥抱，她勉强才挡开。

vocab.ex: He showed deep repentance for his crimes.
vocab.tr: 他对自己的罪行表现出深深的悔意。

vocab.ex: The priest began to intone the ancient prayer.
vocab.tr: 牧师开始吟诵古老的祷文。

vocab.ex: The victor of the tournament will receive a gold trophy.
vocab.tr: 锦标赛的获胜者将获得一个金奖杯。

vocab.ex: He had become a bit paunchy in his middle age.
vocab.tr: 他到了中年有点大腹便便了。

vocab.ex: He was so drunk that his speech was completely unintelligible.
vocab.tr: 他醉得太厉害了，说的话完全听不懂。

vocab.ex: He managed to stagger to his feet after the fall.
vocab.tr: 摔倒后，他摇摇晃晃地站了起来。

vocab.ex: The boring speech received only a brief, token applause.
vocab.tr: 那场无聊的演讲只获得了一阵简短而象征性的掌声。

vocab.ex: She had to fend off a series of difficult questions from the reporters.
vocab.tr: 她不得不挡开记者们一连串刁钻的问题。

gram.name: 用于强调的片段
gram.pattern: A single word or short phrase as a sentence.
gram.function: 在陈述“他喝醉了”（'He’s drunk.'）之后，紧跟一个独立的、只有一个词的句子片段 'Very.'，极大地强调了他醉酒的程度。这种用法比说 'He's very drunk.' 更具戏剧性和冲击力。

example.en: She was tired. Extremely.
example.tr: 她很累。极度地。

gram.constraints: 是一种在叙事中增加节奏感和强调的技巧。

paras.en: The mayor looks distressed. Since all of this is being televised, right now District 12 is the laughingstock of Panem, and he knows it. He quickly tries to pull the attention back to the reaping by introducing Effie Trinket. Bright and bubbly as ever, Effie Trinket trots to the podium and gives her signature, “Happy Hunger Games! And may the odds be ever in your favor!” Her pink hair must be a wig because her curls have shifted slightly off-center since her encounter with Haymitch. She goes on a bit about what an honor it is to be here, although everyone knows she’s just aching to get bumped up to a better district where they have proper victors, not drunks who molest you in front of the entire nation.
paras.cn: 市长看起来很苦恼。由于这一切都在电视上直播，此刻第12区成了帕纳姆的笑柄，他知道这一点。他迅速试图通过介绍艾菲·特林켓，把注意力拉回到收获日上。艾菲·特林켓一如既往地开朗活泼，她小步跑到讲台前，给出了她的标志性问候：“饥饿游戏快乐！愿几率永远对你有利！” 她的粉色头发肯定是个假发，因为自从她和海米契的遭遇后，她的卷发已经稍微偏离了中心。她继续说了一会儿，讲在这里是多么荣幸，尽管每个人都知道她只是渴望被提升到一个更好的区，那里有正派的获胜者，而不是在全国人民面前骚扰你的醉鬼。

vocab.ex: She was deeply distressed by the sad news.
vocab.tr: 她对那个悲伤的消息深感苦恼。

vocab.ex: After his embarrassing mistake, he became the laughingstock of the office.
vocab.tr: 在他犯了那个尴尬的错误后，他成了办公室的笑柄。

vocab.ex: She has a bright and bubbly personality.
vocab.tr: 她性格开朗活泼。

vocab.ex: The little dog trotted happily beside its owner.
vocab.tr: 那只小狗高兴地在主人身边小跑着。

vocab.ex: The chef's signature dish is his famous lasagna.
vocab.tr: 那位厨师的招牌菜是他著名的千层面。

vocab.ex: The picture on the wall was slightly off-center.
vocab.tr: 墙上的画有点偏离中心。

vocab.ex: He went on about his new car for over an hour.
vocab.tr: 他喋喋不休地讲他的新车讲了一个多小时。

vocab.ex: After months of winter, she was aching to feel the warm sun on her skin.
vocab.tr: 经过几个月的冬天，她渴望感受到温暖的阳光照在皮肤上。

vocab.ex: After her excellent performance, she was bumped up to a senior position.
vocab.tr: 在她出色的表现之后，她被提升到了一个高级职位。

gram.name: 外表与现实的对比
gram.pattern: A description of outward appearance followed by the inner reality.
gram.function: 通过将艾菲“开朗活泼”（Bright and bubbly）的外在表现与她内心的真实渴望（'aching to get bumped up to a better district'）进行对比，作者深刻地揭示了国会区人物的虚伪性。这种外表与现实的差距，是整个社会虚假和压迫本质的缩影。

example.en: He appeared calm and confident, but inside he was trembling with fear.
example.tr: 他表面上看起来冷静自信，但内心却因恐惧而颤抖。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过对比来揭示人物复杂性和虚伪性的文学技巧。

paras.en: Through the crowd, I spot Gale looking back at me with a ghost of a smile. As reapings go, this one at least has a slight entertainment factor. But suddenly I am thinking of Gale and his forty-two names in that big glass ball and how the odds are not in his favor. Not compared to a lot of the boys. And maybe he’s thinking the same thing about me because his face darkens and he turns away. “But there are still thousands of slips,” I wish I could whisper to him.
paras.cn: 穿过人群，我看到盖尔回头看着我，脸上带着一丝若有若无的微笑。就收获日而言，这一次至少还有一点娱乐因素。但突然间，我想到了盖尔和他在那个大玻璃球里的四十二个名字，以及几率对他多么不利。和很多男孩相比并不有利。也许他也在想关于我的同样的事情，因为他的脸色暗了下来，转过身去。“但里面还有成千上万的纸条，” 我希望我能对他低声说。

vocab.ex: Even in his sadness, there was a ghost of a smile on his face.
vocab.tr: 即使在悲伤中，他的脸上也带着一丝若有若无的微笑。

vocab.ex: As Mondays go, this one wasn't so bad.
vocab.tr: 就周一而言，今天这个还不算太糟。

vocab.ex: The movie's plot was weak, but it had a high entertainment factor.
vocab.tr: 那部电影的情节很弱，但娱乐性很高。

vocab.ex: The odds of winning the lottery are incredibly low.

vocab.tr: 法官的判决对她有利。

vocab.ex: His expression began to darken when he heard the bad news.
vocab.tr: 当他听到那个坏消息时，他的表情开始变得阴沉。

gram.name: 共同的未言明的想法
gram.pattern: A character infers another's thoughts based on a shared experience and non-verbal cues.
gram.function: 通过“也许他也在想关于我的同样的事情”（推断）和“因为他的脸色暗了下来，转过身去”（非语言线索），作者展现了两个角色之间深度的默契和共情。他们无需言语，就能通过共同的处境和细微的表情变化，理解对方内心的恐惧。这种未言明的交流，深刻地揭示了他们的关系。

example.en: She looked at the clock and then at me. I knew she was thinking it was time to leave.
example.tr: 她看了看时钟，然后又看看我。我知道她在想是时候离开了。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过内心独白和非语言线索来展示角色关系的有效技巧。

paras.en: It’s time for the drawing. Effie Trinket says as she always does, “Ladies first!” and crosses to the glass ball with the girls’ names. She reaches in, digs her hand deep into the ball, and pulls out a slip of paper. The crowd draws in a collective breath and then you can hear a pin drop, and I’m feeling nauseous and so desperately hoping that it’s not me, that it’s not me, that it’s not me. Effie Trinket crosses back to the podium, smoothes the slip of paper, and reads out the name in a clear voice. And it’s not me. It’s Primrose Everdeen.
paras.cn: 抽签的时间到了。艾菲·特林켓像她往常一样说：“女士优先！”然后走到装有女孩名字的玻璃球前。她伸进去，把手深深地探入球中，然后抽出一张纸条。人群集体吸了一口气，然后你便能听到针掉在地上的声音，我感到恶心，并且拼命地希望不是我，不是我，不是我。艾菲·特林켓走回讲台，抚平纸条，用清晰的声音读出名字。不是我。是波丽姆·伊夫狄恩。

gram.name: 同语重复 (Epizeuxis)
gram.pattern: Immediate repetition of a phrase for emphasis.
gram.function: 通过立即、连续地重复 'that it’s not me'，作者使用了“同语重复”（epizeuxis）这一修辞手法。这种重复模仿了主角在极度恐惧和紧张下，内心那种执着、祈祷式的默念。它比只说一次更能强烈地传达出她当时的绝望。

example.en: Please, please, please don't leave me alone.
example.tr: 求求你，求求你，求求你不要离开我一个人。

gram.constraints: 是一种通过纯粹的重复来达到最强强调效果的修辞手法。
